Sentences_from: Zęby są za duże na jamnika, za małe na wyżła.
Sentences_to: The dog's jaw, as shown in the space between these marks, is too broad in my opinion for a terrier and not broad enough for a mastiff.
Translated_sentences: The teeth are too big for a dachshund, too small for a pointer.

Sentences_from: Zostawiłem więc sir Henryka w domu i pojechałem na zwiady.
Sentences_to: I left Sir Henry behind, therefore, not without some prickings of conscience, and drove off upon my new quest.
Translated_sentences: So I left Sir Henry at home and went to scout.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli mają złe względem pana zamiary, mogą je wykonać, zanim zdołamy temu zapobiedz.
Sentences_to: If their intentions are evil they might do you a mischief, and we should be powerless to prevent it.
Translated_sentences: If they have bad intentions towards you, they can do it before we can prevent it.

Sentences_from: Zbiegliśmy z pagórka, goniąc uciekającego co tchu Seldona.
Sentences_to: At the same moment by a lucky chance the moon broke through the clouds.
Translated_sentences: We ran down the hill, chasing Seldon, who was fleeing every breath.

Sentences_from: -- Nie dziw, że znam pańskie stosunki ze słynnym detektywem -- rzekł pan Stapleton. -- Wszak wiadomo powszechnie, iż jesteście w przyjaźni ze sobą.
Sentences_to: "It is useless for us to pretend that we do not know you, Dr. Watson," said he. "The records of your detective have reached us here, and you could not celebrate him without being known yourself.
Translated_sentences: "No wonder I know your relationship with the famous detective," said Mr. Stapleton. "After all, it is well known that you are in friendship with each other.

Sentences_from: Zagasłe oczy świeciły jeszcze, zakrwawiony pysk ział ogniem.
Sentences_to: Even now, in the stillness of death, the huge jaws seemed to be dripping with a bluish flame and the small, deep-set, cruel eyes were ringed with fire.
Translated_sentences: The extinguished eyes were still shining, the bloodied muzzle was breathing fire.

Sentences_from: Zacny starzec, zwiedziony pozorami, polubił Stapletona i za jego pośrednictwem świadczył dużo dobrego, między innymi pani Laurze Lyons.
Sentences_to: His plans were suddenly brought to a head by his knowledge that Sir Charles was about to leave the Hall on the advice of Dr. Mortimer, with whose opinion he himself pretended to coincide. He must act at once, or his victim might get beyond his power.
Translated_sentences: The noble old man, deceived by appearances, liked Stapleton and through him he did a lot of good, including Mrs. Laura Lyons.

Sentences_from: Wiesz, że mam sen lekki, a od chwili, gdym tu przybył w charakterze anioła-stróża, sypiam z otwartemi oczyma, jak zając.
Sentences_to: You are aware that I am not a very sound sleeper, and since I have been on guard in this house my slumbers have been lighter than ever.
Translated_sentences: You know that I have a light dream, and from the moment I came here as a guardian angel, I sleep with my eyes open, like a hare.

Sentences_from: Sir Henryk był bardziej rad, niż zdziwiony widokiem Holmesa; spodziewał się bowiem, że ostatnie wypadki skłonią go do przybycia.
Sentences_to: Sir Henry was more pleased than surprised to see Sherlock Holmes, for he had for some days been expecting that recent events would bring him down from London.
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry was more glad than surprised to see Holmes; for he expected that the recent events would induce him to come.

Sentences_from: Niezrażeni tem, postanowiliśmy próbę ponowić. Następnej nocy zgasiliśmy lampkę, i zapaliwszy papierosy, czekaliśmy, co będzie dalej.
Sentences_to: It was incredible how slowly the hours crawled by, and yet we were helped through it by the same sort of patient interest which the hunter must feel as he watches the trap into which he hopes the game may wander.
Translated_sentences: Undeaded, we decided to try again. The next night we turned off the lamp, and having lit our cigarettes, we waited to see what would happen next.

Sentences_from: Obiecywałem sobie, że znajdę nieznajomego i że musi mi wyznać, dlaczego tu przebywa.
Sentences_to: We'll teach these magnates that they cannot ride roughshod over the rights of the commoners, confound them!
Translated_sentences: I promised myself that I would find a stranger and that he had to tell me why he was here.

Sentences_from: -- Jest trzecie wejście przez altanę, na drugim końcu alei.
Sentences_to: "There is an exit through a summer-house at the far end."
Translated_sentences: "There is a third entrance through the gazebo, at the other end of the avenue.

Sentences_from: Sprawa powikłała się przez ucieczkę więźnia Seldona i jego porozumienie się z Barrymorami.
Sentences_to: I was able to establish the identity of the man and the woman and knew at last exactly how I stood.
Translated_sentences: The case was complicated by the escape of prisoner Seldon and his agreement with the Barrymors.

Sentences_from: Chciałbym już, żeby nowa służba zwolniła mnie z dozoru nad pałacem.
Sentences_to: What does it mean? It means no good to anyone of the name of Baskerville, and very glad I shall be to be quit of it all on the day that Sir Henry's new servants are ready to take over the Hall."
Translated_sentences: I would like the new ministry to release me from the supervision of the palace.

Sentences_from: -- Czy pan sądzi, że kobieta może bezkarnie odwiedzać mężczyznę bezżennego o takiej godzinie?
Sentences_to: "Do you think a woman could go alone at that hour to a bachelor's house?"
Translated_sentences: "Do you think that a woman can visit an unmarrying man at such an hour with impunity?"

Sentences_from: Nie mówię teraz jako lekarz, lecz jako wykonawca testamentu sir Karola.
Sentences_to: I speak not as a medical man but as a trustee and executor of Sir Charles's will."
Translated_sentences: I am not speaking now as a doctor, but as an executor of Sir Charles' will.

Sentences_from: Widywaliśmy go często, i jego śmierć była dla nas ciosem.
Sentences_to: We knew him well, and miss him more than I can tell.
Translated_sentences: We have seen him often, and his death was a blow to us.

Sentences_from: -- Zapytaj na stacyi, czy niema listu do mnie.
Sentences_to: "And ask at the station office if there is a message for me."
Translated_sentences: "Ask me if there's a silent letter to me.

Sentences_from: Gdym zobaczył po raz pierwszy blask od soczewki, nie mogłem zmiarkować, co to takiego.
Sentences_to: I could not make it out when first I saw the light flashing upon the lens."
Translated_sentences: When I saw the glow from the lens for the first time, I couldn't mediact what it was.

Sentences_from: Skoro pałac zostanie urządzony, brak w nim będzie tylko -- pięknej pani domu.
Sentences_to: The baronet has been in communication with the architect who prepared the plans for Sir Charles, and with a contractor from London, so that we may expect great changes to begin here soon. There have been decorators and furnishers up from Plymouth, and it is evident that our friend has large ideas, and means to spare no pains or expense to restore the grandeur of his family.
Translated_sentences: Since the palace is furnished, there will be only a beautiful lady of the house missing from it.

Sentences_from: Byłem w trudnem położeniu, a gdym tak stał zafrasowany, mój towarzysz odwrócił się i poszedł przez łąkę. Czyniłem sobie wyrzuty, że go pozostawiam własnemu losowi.
Sentences_to: It put me in a most awkward position.
Translated_sentences: I was in a difficult position, and as I stood there in dim, my companion turned and walked through the meadow. I reproached myself for leaving him to his own fate.

Sentences_from: -- Widać z niego, że ktoś śledzi łąkę i przyległe do niej pustkowia i trzęsawiska -- rzekł doktor Mortimer.
Sentences_to: "It seems to show that someone knows more than we do about what goes on upon the moor," said Dr. Mortimer.
Translated_sentences: "You can see from it that someone is following the meadow and the adjacent wastelands and bogs," said Dr. Mortimer.

Sentences_from: Wbiegliśmy do pokoju z pistoletami w garści.
Sentences_to: Pistol in hand, we all three rushed into the room.
Translated_sentences: We ran into the room with guns in hand.

Sentences_from: -- „Dr. Watson pojechał do Coombe-Tracey”.
Sentences_to: Dr. Watson has gone to Coombe Tracey.
Translated_sentences: "Dr. Watson went to Coombe-Tracey."

Sentences_from: Tylko dwa okna były oświecone. Wtem światło zgasło w kuchni; pozostało tylko w pokoju jadalnym, w którym morderca i jego ofiara siedzieli przy kieliszkach i cygarach.
Sentences_to: Already the first thin wisps of it were curling across the golden square of the lighted window. The farther wall of the orchard was already invisible, and the trees were standing out of a swirl of white vapour.
Translated_sentences: Only two windows were enlightened. Then the light went out in the kitchen; it remained only in the dining room, where the murderer and his victim sat with glasses and cigars.

Sentences_from: -- Dziwisz się pan zapewne, że rozpięliśmy tutaj namioty? -- rzekł Stapleton, jakby w odpowiedzi namoje myśli. -- A jednak dobrze nam i czujemy się szczęśliwi. Prawda, Beryl?
Sentences_to: "Queer spot to choose, is it not?" said he as if in answer to my thought. "And yet we manage to make ourselves fairly happy, do we not, Beryl?"
Translated_sentences: "Are you surprised that we have unzipped tents here?" Stapleton said, as if in response to his thoughts. "And yet we are fine and we feel happy. Right, Beryl?

Sentences_from: To też nie pojmuję, dlaczego odrzuca jego zabiegi, nie pytając nawet, czy siostra jest mu przychylna, a dziwi mnie nadto, że ona słucha go ślepo. Nasze domysły na ten temat przerwał sam Stapleton, który przybył po południu, aby przeprosić baroneta za swoją porywczość.
Sentences_to: "I don't say now that he isn't a crazy man," said Sir Henry; "I can't forget the look in his eyes when he ran at me this morning, but I must allow that no man could make a more handsome apology than he has done."
Translated_sentences: I also don't understand why she rejects his treatments without even asking if his sister is sympathetic to him, and I'm also surprised that she listens to him blindly. Our guesses on this subject were interrupted by Stapleton himself, who arrived in the afternoon to apologize to the baronet for his impetuousness.

Sentences_from: -- Proszę cię, zakradnij się pod te okna i zobacz, co oni tam robią, ale na miłość Boską, ostrożnie, żeby nie zmiarkowali, że są śledzeni.
Sentences_to: "The blinds are up. You know the lie of the land best. Creep forward quietly and see what they are doing--but for heaven's sake don't let them know that they are watched!"
Translated_sentences: "I beg you, sneak under those windows and see what they're doing there, but for God's sake, be careful not to let them soften that they're being followed.

Sentences_from: On nie winien. Robił to dla mnie, bo go o to prosiłam.
Sentences_to: He has done nothing except for my sake and because I asked him."
Translated_sentences: He is not to blame. He did it for me because I asked him to.

Sentences_from: Tym sposobem, korzystając z legendy, ów łotr wystraszył na śmierć sir Karola.
Sentences_to: This paste in the tin is no doubt the luminous mixture with which the creature was daubed.
Translated_sentences: In this way, using legend, this thief scared Sir Charles to death.

Sentences_from: -- I ja także -- wtrącił sir Baskerville.
Sentences_to: "And so did I," said Baskerville. "Every inch of it."
Translated_sentences: "And so am I," interjected Sir Baskerville.

Sentences_from: Zresztą ta skrytość płynie może i z ostrożności, która nie pozwala mu wypowiadać się przed nikim.
Sentences_to: My nerves thrilled with anticipation when at last the cold wind upon our faces and the dark, void spaces on either side of the narrow road told me that we were back upon the moor once again.
Translated_sentences: Besides, this secrecy may come from caution, which does not allow him to speak in front of anyone.

Sentences_from: Jego następne słowa zdjęły mi kamień z serca.
Sentences_to: But his next remark took a weight from my mind.
Translated_sentences: His next words took the stone off my heart.

Sentences_from: Przedstawiciel pierwszorzędnego rodu jest trapiony przez łotra i wyzyskiwacza.
Sentences_to: At the present instant one of the most revered names in England is being besmirched by a blackmailer, and only I can stop a disastrous scandal.
Translated_sentences: The representative of the first-class family is troubled by a villain and an exploiter.

Sentences_from: -- To Seldon, więzień, który zbiegł z Princetown.
Sentences_to: "It is Selden, the man who escaped from Princetown."
Translated_sentences: "This is Seldon, the prisoner who escaped from Princetown.

Sentences_from: Obaj z sir Henrykiem zerwaliśmy się na równe nogi.
Sentences_to: It's about poor Sir Charles's death."
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry and I both got back on our feet.

Sentences_from: Słuchaj, Watson: żyjesz już ze mną parę tygodni, powiedz mi szczerze, czyś nie spostrzegł we mnie jakiego umysłowego zboczenia?
Sentences_to: What's the matter with me, anyhow? You've lived near me for some weeks, Watson.
Translated_sentences: Listen, Watson: you've been living with me for a few weeks now, tell me honestly, didn't you see in me what mental perversion?

Sentences_from: Gdym schodził z wózka, spostrzegłem, że patrzy po przez moje ramię ze strachem w oczach.
Sentences_to: I had descended from my gig and was standing in front of him, when I saw his eyes fix themselves over my shoulder, and stare past me with an expression of the most dreadful horror.
Translated_sentences: As I walked out of the stroller, I noticed him looking over my shoulder with fear in his eyes.

Sentences_from: A nuż go spotka nieszczęście!... Na samą myśl o tem, krew uderzyła mi do głowy.
Sentences_to: I was at a loss what to say or what to do, and before I had made up my mind he picked up his cane and was gone.
Translated_sentences: And maybe misfortune will befall him!... At the very thought of this, blood hit my head.

Sentences_from: -- Dlaczego mnie pan pyta? -- rzekła ostro.
Sentences_to: "What is the object of these questions?" she asked sharply.
Translated_sentences: "Why are you asking me?" "- she said sharply.

Sentences_from: -- Tak; jest jeszcze u nas.
Sentences_to: "Yes, sir, he is still with us."
Translated_sentences: -- Yes; is still with us.

Sentences_from: Dał mi do ręki nowy atut. Myślę go użyć.

Translated_sentences: He gave me a new asset. I think I'm thinking of using it.

Sentences_from: Chodzi mi o fakt zagadkowy, który zdarzył się niedawno; muszę rozstrzygnąć zagadkę, w ciągu dwudziestu czterech godzin.
Sentences_to: A most practical, pressing matter, which must be decided within twenty-four hours.
Translated_sentences: I mean a puzzling fact that happened recently; I have to solve the mystery within twenty-four hours.

Sentences_from: Wskoczył na krzesło, i trzymając świecę w lewej ręce, prawą osłonił szeroki kapelusz i włosy.
Sentences_to: He stood upon a chair, and, holding up the light in his left hand, he curved his right arm over the broad hat and round the long ringlets.
Translated_sentences: He jumped into a chair, and holding a candle in his left hand, covered his wide hat and hair with his right hand.

Sentences_from: Czyś pan jej zawiłości rozplątał? My z Watsonem tyle wiemy dziś, co na początku.
Sentences_to: I don't know that Watson and I are much the wiser since we came down."
Translated_sentences: Have you unlearned its intricacies? Watson and I know as much today as we did in the beginning.

Sentences_from: Od pierwszego rzutu oka spostrzegłem, że jest niezwykłą: zdradza zdolności, rzekłbym nawet -- geniusz dedukcyjny.
Sentences_to: I had hardly expected so dolichocephalic a skull or such well-marked supra-orbital development. Would you have any objection to my running my finger along your parietal fissure?
Translated_sentences: At first glance, I saw that it was extraordinary: it betrayed abilities, I would even say -- deductive genius.

Sentences_from: Tym wszystkim sąsiadom musisz przyglądać się bacznie, aby poznać dokładnie ich charakter, ich cele, upodobania i t. d.
Sentences_to: There is Mr. Frankland, of Lafter Hall, who is also an unknown factor, and there are one or two other neighbours. These are the folk who must be your very special study."
Translated_sentences: You need to watch all these neighbors closely to get to know exactly their character, their goals, tastes, and so on.

Sentences_from: Szliśmy powoli przez Regent Street. Doktor Mortimer i jego towarzysz oddawna już zniknęli nam z oczu.
Sentences_to: We had been sauntering slowly down Regent Street during this conversation, and Dr. Mortimer, with his companion, had long vanished in front of us.
Translated_sentences: We walked slowly through Regent Street. Dr. Mortimer and his companion have long since disappeared from our sight.

Sentences_from: -- Tak, na własne oczy; tak wyraźnie, jak teraz widzę pana.
Sentences_to: "As clearly as I see you."
Translated_sentences: Yes, with your own eyes; as clearly as I see you now.

Sentences_from: -- Warunki zmieniły się. My dwoje wystarczaliśmy sir Karolowi, ale jaśnie pan zechce zapewne żyć dworniej, przyjmować gości i będzie potrzebował więcej służby.
Sentences_to: "I only meant, sir, that Sir Charles led a very retired life, and we were able to look after his wants. You would, naturally, wish to have more company, and so you will need changes in your household."
Translated_sentences: "Conditions have changed. The two of us were enough for Sir Charles, but clearly you will probably want to live a more courtly life, receive guests, and will need more service.

Sentences_from: Byłem zachwycony jej urodą, lecz przyjrzawszy się bliżej, dostrzegłem ostry wyraz ust i oczu, psujący ogólną harmonię.
Sentences_to: But the second was criticism. There was something subtly wrong with the face, some coarseness of expression, some hardness, perhaps, of eye, some looseness of lip which marred its perfect beauty.
Translated_sentences: I was delighted with her beauty, but when I looked closer, I saw a sharp expression on her lips and eyes, spoiling the overall harmony.

Sentences_from: Dotarłem do skały Black-Tor, na której szczycie stał wówczas nieznajomy. Z jej wyżyn spojrzałem na szarą równinę.
Sentences_to: Rain squalls drifted across their russet face, and the heavy, slate-coloured clouds hung low over the landscape, trailing in gray wreaths down the sides of the fantastic hills.
Translated_sentences: I reached the Black-Tor rock, on top of which a stranger was standing at the time. From its heights I looked at the gray plain.

Sentences_from: Owego wieczora, przed przybyciem sir Henryka na obiad, wśród małżonków wynikła sprzeczka. Beryl nazwała męża zbrodniarzem; rozwścieczony, chcąc ją dotknąć boleśnie, oznajmił jej, że kocha inną.
Sentences_to: Her fidelity turned in an instant to bitter hatred and he saw that she would betray him. He tied her up, therefore, that she might have no chance of warning Sir Henry, and he hoped, no doubt, that when the whole country-side put down the baronet's death to the curse of his family, as they certainly would do, he could win his wife back to accept an accomplished fact and to keep silent upon what she knew.
Translated_sentences: That evening, before Sir Henry arrived for dinner, an argument arose among the spouses. Beryl called her husband a criminal; Enraged, wanting to touch her painfully, he told her that he loved another.

Sentences_from: -- Spodziewam się, że i panowie pójdziecie ze mną.
Sentences_to: "I hope that you will come also.
Translated_sentences: "I expect you to come with me as well.

Sentences_from: Pan sądzi, że ten chłopak jest pastuchem?

Sentences_from: Jaśnie pan znajdzie wodę ciepłą w swojej ubieralni.
Sentences_to: You will find hot water in your rooms.
Translated_sentences: You will find warm water in your dressing room.

Sentences_from: Stary baronet nie wychodził nigdy za obręb pałacu po zachodzie słońca.
Sentences_to: "But it was some time coming. The old gentleman could not be decoyed outside of his grounds at night.
Translated_sentences: The old baronet never went outside the palace after sunset.

Sentences_from: Chciałem się przysłużyć Papieżowi i straciłem z oczu to, co się jednocześnie działo w Anglii. Ten artykuł, powiadasz pan, zawiera fakty, znane powszechnie?
Sentences_to: This article, you say, contains all the public facts?"
Translated_sentences: I wanted to serve the Pope and I lost sight of what was happening in England at the same time. This article, you say, contains facts, known to all?

Sentences_from: To też cały dzień spędziłem w klubie i dopiero około dziewiątej powróciłem do mieszkania przy Bakerstreet.
Sentences_to: I therefore spent the day at my club and did not return to Baker Street until evening. It was nearly nine o'clock when I found myself in the sitting-room once more.
Translated_sentences: I also spent the whole day in the club and only around nine o'clock I returned to the apartment on Bakerstreet.

Sentences_from: Nie pojechałam, bo mi coś przeszkodziło.
Sentences_to: Something intervened to prevent my going."
Translated_sentences: I didn't go because something was bothering me.

Sentences_from: -- Kto wiedział, że pan zatrzyma się w Northumberland Hotel? -- spytał Holmes, spoglądając bystro na swego klienta.
Sentences_to: "Who knew that you were going to the Northumberland Hotel?" asked Holmes, glancing keenly across at our visitor.
Translated_sentences: "Who knew you were staying at the Northumberland Hotel?" Holmes asked, looking at his client.

Sentences_from: Zostawiliśmy sir Henryka i podążyliśmy ku domowi Stapletona. -- Słyszał wystrzały i domyślił się, że jego „sztuka” wyszła na jaw.
Sentences_to: "It's a thousand to one against our finding him at the house," he continued as we retraced our steps swiftly down the path.
Translated_sentences: We left Sir Henry and went to Stapleton's house. He heard gunshots and guessed that his "art" had come to light.

Sentences_from: „Towarzysze hulanki rzucili się do koni, chwycili pistolety i pognali za swoim amfitryonem, a było ich razem trzynastu.
Sentences_to: "Now, for some space the revellers stood agape, unable to understand all that had been done in such haste.
Translated_sentences: "The comrades of the revelry rushed to the horses, grabbed their pistols and chased after their amphitrion, and there were thirteen of them together.

Sentences_from: Stapleton zamykał żonę na klucz a sam, przyprawiwszy brodę, dla niepoznaki, śledził każdy krok doktora Mortimer, jeździł za nim na Baker-Street, a następnie na dworzec i do hotelu Northumberland.
Sentences_to: Here he kept his wife imprisoned in her room while he, disguised in a beard, followed Dr. Mortimer to Baker Street and afterwards to the station and to the Northumberland Hotel. His wife had some inkling of his plans; but she had such a fear of her husband--a fear founded upon brutal ill-treatment--that she dare not write to warn the man whom she knew to be in danger.
Translated_sentences: Stapleton locked his wife and, having seasoned his beard for the sake of insefect, followed Dr. Mortimer's every step, followed him to Baker-Street, and then to the station and to the Northumberland Hotel.

Sentences_from: Oczy jej biegły niespokojnie za bratem, przyśpieszyła kroku i zrównała się ze mną. Uchyliłem kapelusza i chciałem się przedstawić, lecz nie dała mi dojść do słowa.
Sentences_to: I had raised my hat and was about to make some explanatory remark, when her own words turned all my thoughts into a new channel.
Translated_sentences: Her eyes ran restlessly behind her brother, she stepped up and leveled with me. I opened my hat and wanted to introduce myself, but she didn't let me get to the word.

Sentences_from: -- Dużo jest psów w okolicy.
Sentences_to: "There are many sheep-dogs on the moor?"
Translated_sentences: "There are a lot of dogs in the area.

Sentences_from: Brat jest wątły i niezbyt silny, siostra, jakkolwiek rosła i dobrze zbudowana, nie mogłaby stawić oporu takiemu zbójowi.
Sentences_to: They would be helpless in the hands of a desperate fellow like this Notting Hill criminal, if he could once effect an entrance.
Translated_sentences: The brother is fray and not very strong, the sister, however grown and well built, could not resist such a robber.

Sentences_from: -- Powiadają, że to szczekanie psa Baskervillów -- odparłem.
Sentences_to: "They say it is the cry of the Hound of the Baskervilles."
Translated_sentences: "They say it's the barking of the Baskervilles' dog," I replied.

Sentences_from: Pijani towarzysze słuchali go w przerażonem milczeniu, tylko jeden, gorszy, a może bardziej pijany od innych, poddał myśl, aby za dziewczyną puścić w pogoń psy podwórzowe.
Sentences_to: And while the revellers stood aghast at the fury of the man, one more wicked or, it may be, more drunken than the rest, cried out that they should put the hounds upon her.
Translated_sentences: Drunken comrades listened to him in terrified silence, only one, inferior, or perhaps more drunk than the others, gave up the idea of chasing the girl yard dogs.

Sentences_from: Na lewo, wśród gęstych chmur, po nad drzewami sterczały wieżyce Baskerville-Hall.
Sentences_to: In the distant hollow on the left, half hidden by the mist, the two thin towers of Baskerville Hall rose above the trees.
Translated_sentences: To the left, among the dense clouds, above the trees protruded the towers of Baskerville-Hall.

Sentences_from: List doszedł rąk baroneta i był pierwsza zapowiedzią niebezpieczeństwa.
Sentences_to: With characteristic promptness and audacity he set about this at once, and we cannot doubt that the boots or chamber-maid of the hotel was well bribed to help him in his design.
Translated_sentences: The letter reached the hands of the baronet and was the first harbinger of danger.

Sentences_from: -- Doktor Mortimer mieszkał już tam zapewne?
Sentences_to: "But Dr. Mortimer was no doubt already stopping there?"
Translated_sentences: "Dr. Mortimer must have lived there before?"

Sentences_from: Posłaliśmy po Niemca, ale twierdził, że o niczem nie wie i nie umiał wyjaśnić tego dziwnego zdarzenia.
Sentences_to: "In that case the waiter must have placed it there while we were lunching."
Translated_sentences: We sent for a German, but he claimed that he did not know an antics and could not explain this strange event.

Sentences_from: -- Czy pani zapamiętała daty swoich listów?
Sentences_to: "Have you the dates of those letters?"
Translated_sentences: "Do you remember the dates of your letters?"

Sentences_from: Choć jeszcze młody wiekiem, był już przygarbiony; na jego twarzy malowała się dobra wola względem ludzi.
Sentences_to: Though young, his long back was already bowed, and he walked with a forward thrust of his head and a general air of peering benevolence.
Translated_sentences: Though still young, he was already hunched over; on his face there was a good will towards people.

Sentences_from: Po za nim stała kobieta; pomagała mu wyjmować kuferki.
Sentences_to: She came out and helped the man to hand down our bags.
Translated_sentences: Behind him stood a woman; she helped him take out his trunks.

Sentences_from: Był tak wystraszony, że świeca podskakiwała mu w ręku. -- Przyszedłem zobaczyć, czy okno zamknięte...
Sentences_to: His agitation was so great that he could hardly speak, and the shadows sprang up and down from the shaking of his candle.
Translated_sentences: He was so scared that a candle jumped in his hand. "I came to see if the window was closed...

Sentences_from: Moja żona i ja będziemy starali się dogadzać jaśnie panu, dopóki nie znajdzie nowej służby.
Sentences_to: My wife and I will be happy, Sir Henry, to stay with you until you have made your fresh arrangements, but you will understand that under the new conditions this house will require a considerable staff."
Translated_sentences: My wife and I will try to please you brightly until she finds a new ministry.

Sentences_from: Zostałem z nim przez cały wieczór i wtedy, tłómacząc swe wzburzenie, opowiedział mi całą tę historyę.
Sentences_to: I stayed with him all the evening, and it was on that occasion, to explain the emotion which he had shown, that he confided to my keeping that narrative which I read to you when first I came.
Translated_sentences: I stayed with him all evening, and then, in his agitation, he told me the whole story.

Sentences_from: Ale teraz, gdy jaśnie pan okazał nam tyle dobroci, uważam sobie za obowiązek wyznać to jaśnie panu.
Sentences_to: But now you have been kind to us, and I feel as if it would be treating you unfairly not to tell you all that I know about the matter."
Translated_sentences: But now that you have clearly shown us so much kindness, I consider it my duty to confess it clearly to you.

Sentences_from: Wstał i wszedł do jaskini. -- Ha! widzę, że Cartwright przyniósł mi prowianty...
Sentences_to: He rose and peeped into the hut. "Ha, I see that Cartwright has brought up some supplies.
Translated_sentences: He got up and entered the cave. -- Ha! I see that Cartwright brought me provisions...

Sentences_from: -- Kogo ja widzę! -- rzekł. -- Jeśli mnie oczy nie mylą, doktor Watson. Nie spodziewałem się spotkać pana tutaj...
Sentences_to: A figure was approaching us over the moor, and I saw the dull red glow of a cigar.
Translated_sentences: "Who do I see!" ", he said. "If my eyes don't confuse me, Dr. Watson. I didn't expect to meet you here...

Sentences_from: Zbliżywszy się, spostrzegłem dwa kamienie, stojące prostopadle; jeden leżał na nich poziomo.
Sentences_to: But there were ample signs that I had not come upon a false scent. This was certainly where the man lived.
Translated_sentences: As I approached, I saw two stones standing perpendicular; one was lying on them horizontally.

Sentences_from: -- Jego żona! -- szeptała. -- Jego żona!
Sentences_to: "His wife!" she said again. "His wife!
Translated_sentences: His wife! She whispered. His wife!

Sentences_from: -- Nasza sprawa zaczyna się zaokrąglać -- mówił Holmes, gdy w parę minut potem staliśmy na dworcu, oczekując londyńskiego pociągu. -- Jest to najdziwniejsza zbrodnia, jaka się zdarzyła w naszem stuleciu.
Sentences_to: "Our case becomes rounded off, and difficulty after difficulty thins away in front of us," said Holmes as we stood waiting for the arrival of the express from town. "I shall soon be in the position of being able to put into a single connected narrative one of the most singular and sensational crimes of modern times.
Translated_sentences: "Our case is beginning to round up," holmes said as we stood at the station a few minutes later, waiting for the London train. "This is the strangest crime that has happened in our century.

Sentences_from: Jednego tylko obawiam się, a mianowicie, żeby on nie wykonał swego zamiaru, zanim będziemy gotowi do walki.
Sentences_to: There is but one danger which can threaten us. It is that he should strike before we are ready to do so.
Translated_sentences: There is only one thing I fear, and that is that he will not carry out his purpose before we are ready to fight.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli będę zmuszony wezwać pomocy policyi, wtedy dopiero przekonasz się pani, jak dalece jesteś skompromitowaną.
Sentences_to: If I have to call in the aid of the police you will find how seriously you are compromised.
Translated_sentences: If I am forced to call for the help of the police, then you will see how disgraced you are.

Sentences_from: Zapewne mógł był wyjść na spacer, ale nie w taką noc, ciemną, wilgotną.
Sentences_to: We can understand his taking an evening stroll, but the ground was damp and the night inclement.
Translated_sentences: He probably could have gone out for a walk, but not on such a night, dark, damp.

Sentences_from: -- Przypuszczam jednak, że pragniesz pan zasięgnąć mojej rady w sprawie aktualniejszej i bardziej realnej -- rzekł Holmes.
Sentences_to: "But I understand that it is something more modern and practical upon which you wish to consult me?"
Translated_sentences: "But I suppose you would seek my advice on a matter more actual and more real," said Holmes.

Sentences_from: Podczas gdym ja śledził Stapletona, on śledził ciebie, tak, że wiedziałem o każdym twoim kroku.
Sentences_to: When I was watching Stapleton, Cartwright was frequently watching you, so that I was able to keep my hand upon all the strings.
Translated_sentences: While I was following Stapleton, he was following you, so that I knew about your every step.

Sentences_from: Stanęliśmy opodal i czekaliśmy półtory godziny. Potem ci gentlemanowie przeszli mimo nas, mój pan kazał mi jechać powoli przez Baker-Street, a potem przez Regent Street, do połowy.
Sentences_to: Then my gentleman threw up the trap, and he cried that I should drive right away to Waterloo Station as hard as I could go. I whipped up the mare and we were there under the ten minutes.
Translated_sentences: We stood around and waited an hour and a half. Then these gentlemen passed in spite of us, my master told me to drive slowly through Baker-Street, and then through Regent Street, halfway.

Sentences_from: Czasami zastanawiam się, czy jej nie trapią wyrzuty sumienia, a chwilami posądzam Barrymora, iż jest tyranem.
Sentences_to: Sometimes I wonder if she has a guilty memory which haunts her, and sometimes I suspect Barrymore of being a domestic tyrant.
Translated_sentences: Sometimes I wonder if she is troubled by remorse, and sometimes I suspect Barrymor of being a tyrant.

Sentences_from: Kochany Holmes! Pozostawiłem cię wprawdzie długo bez wiadomości, za to dziś pragnę cię odszkodować.
Sentences_to: MY DEAR HOLMES,--If I was compelled to leave you without much news during the early days of my mission you must acknowledge that I am making up for lost time, and that events are now crowding thick and fast upon us.
Translated_sentences: Dear Holmes! Although I have left you without news for a long time, today I want to compensate you.

Sentences_from: -- Dlaczego pan nie chce zrozumieć, że ta przestroga ma pańskie dobro na względzie?
Sentences_to: "Man, man!" she cried. "Can you not tell when a warning is for your own good?
Translated_sentences: "Why don't you want to understand that this warning has your best interests in mind?"

Sentences_from: Jednak szkoda, że nie zdołaliśmy go sami schwytać.
Sentences_to: He had not seen this lonely man upon the tor and could not feel the thrill which his strange presence and his commanding attitude had given to me.
Translated_sentences: However, it is a pity that we did not manage to capture him ourselves.

Sentences_from: Łatwiej mu było umknąć na Regent-Street, niż na tej otwartej równinie.
Sentences_to: And I've closed the wood where the Fernworthy folk used to picnic.
Translated_sentences: It was easier for him to escape to Regent Street than to this open plain.

Sentences_from: W świetle promieni słonecznych, ślizgających się po starych zbrojach, sala jadalna wydała nam się weselszą, gdyśmy zasiedli do śniadania.
Sentences_to: As Sir Henry and I sat at breakfast the sunlight flooded in through the high mullioned windows, throwing watery patches of colour from the coats of arms which covered them. The dark panelling glowed like bronze in the golden rays, and it was hard to realize that this was indeed the chamber which had struck such a gloom into our souls upon the evening before.
Translated_sentences: In the light of the sun's rays gliding over the old armor, the dining room seemed happier to us when we sat down to breakfast.

Sentences_from: Usta jej poruszyły się bezdźwięcznie, wyszeptała „nie” tak cicho, że domyśliłem się raczej, niż usłyszałem to słowo.
Sentences_to: Her dry lips could not speak the "No" which I saw rather than heard.
Translated_sentences: Her lips moved unsoundingly, she whispered "no" so quietly that I guessed rather than heard the word.

Sentences_from: -- Wielu już przypłaciło życiem taką chętkę.
Sentences_to: "You would naturally think so and the thought has cost several their lives before now.
Translated_sentences: "Many have already paid with their lives for such a will.

Sentences_from: Na płaskim, wygrążonym kamieniu, który zapewne służył przedhistorycznemu człowiekowi za łoże, była kołdra, zawinięta w pled, na ziemi pozostał jeszcze popiół od zagaszonego ogniska, obok były rondelki i blaszana konewka z wodą, w drugim rogu dostrzegłem butelkę z _ginem_.
Sentences_to: Beside it lay some cooking utensils and a bucket half-full of water. A litter of empty tins showed that the place had been occupied for some time, and I saw, as my eyes became accustomed to the checkered light, a pannikin and a half-full bottle of spirits standing in the corner.
Translated_sentences: On a flat, scavenger stone, which probably served a prehistoric man as a bed, there was a quilt, wrapped in plaids, on the ground there was still ash from the extinguished bonfire, next to it were saucepans and a tin watering can, in the other corner I saw a bottle with _gin_.

Sentences_from: Jest doktor Mortimer, ale ten wydaje mi się zupełnie uczciwym; jest jego żona, o której nic nie wiemy.
Sentences_to: There is our friend Dr. Mortimer, whom I believe to be entirely honest, and there is his wife, of whom we know nothing.
Translated_sentences: There is Dr. Mortimer, but this one seems to me to be quite honest; there is his wife, about whom we know nothing.

Sentences_from: „W ciągu ostatnich paru miesięcy spostrzegłem, że system nerwowy sir Karola był nadwerężony.
Sentences_to: "Within the last few months it became increasingly plain to me that Sir Charles's nervous system was strained to the breaking point.
Translated_sentences: "In the last few months I have noticed that Sir Charles' nervous system has been strained.

Sentences_from: I tak, naprzykład, twierdzisz, że laska jest darem jakiegoś prowincyonalnego klubu myśliwskiego. Ja przypuszczam, że ofiarowali ją lekarzowi pensyonarze szpitala Charing Cross (C. C. H.).
Sentences_to: I would suggest, for example, that a presentation to a doctor is more likely to come from a hospital than from a hunt, and that when the initials 'C.C.' are placed before that hospital the words 'Charing Cross' very naturally suggest themselves."
Translated_sentences: And so, for example, you claim that the chick is a gift from some provincial hunting club. I suppose they offered it to the charing cross hospital doctor (C.C. H.).

Sentences_from: -- Jakim sposobem dowiedziałeś się, że ta kobieta jest jego żoną? -- spytałem.
Sentences_to: "But are you sure of this, Holmes? How do you know that the woman is his wife?"
Translated_sentences: How did you find out that this woman was his wife?" I asked.

Sentences_from: Dorożkarz spojrzał na niego ze zdziwieniem. -- Cóż ja panu mam mówić, kiedy pan sam wie wszystko -- odparł. -- Ten pan powiedział mi, że należy do policyi, że jest detektywem, i kazał milczeć.
Sentences_to: The man looked surprised and a little embarrassed. "Why, there's no good my telling you things, for you seem to know as much as I do already," said he. "The truth is that the gentleman told me that he was a detective and that I was to say nothing about him to anyone."
Translated_sentences: The cab driver looked at him with surprise. "What am I to tell you when you know everything," he replied. "This gentleman told me that he belonged to the police, that he was a detective, and told me to remain silent.

Sentences_from: Pędził co tchu, wymachiwał rękoma, a gdy się z nimi zrównał -- tupał nogami i zapewne krzyczał i robił wymówki sir Henrykowi. Ten widocznie usprawiedliwiał się.
Sentences_to: I ran down the hill therefore and met the baronet at the bottom. His face was flushed with anger and his brows were wrinkled, like one who is at his wit's ends what to do.
Translated_sentences: He rushed his breath, waved his arms, and when he leveled with them -- he stamped his feet and must have been screaming and making excuses for Sir Henry. This one apparently justified himself.

Sentences_from: -- Nie daruję sobie nigdy, żem go zostawił samego... -- szepnąłem.
Sentences_to: "The brute! the brute!" I cried with clenched hands. "Oh Holmes, I shall never forgive myself for having left him to his fate."
Translated_sentences: "I never forgive myself for leaving him alone," I whispered.

Sentences_from: Z dnia na dzień spodziewaliśmy się, że opuści te strony, lecz dopóki tu jest, my nie możemy go opuścić. Jeżeli kto zawinił, to ja, nie mój mąż; on go ukrywał i żywił, przez wzgląd na mnie...
Sentences_to: Every day we hoped that he was gone, but as long as he was there we could not desert him. That is the whole truth, as I am an honest Christian woman, and you will see that if there is blame in the matter it does not lie with my husband, but with me, for whose sake he has done all that he has."
Translated_sentences: Overnight we expected him to leave these sites, but as long as he is here, we cannot leave him. If anyone was at fault, it was me, not my husband; he hid it and fed it, for my sake...

Sentences_from: -- Poprostu sprzyjamy i dopomagamy łotrowi...
Sentences_to: "I guess we are aiding and abetting a felony, Watson?
Translated_sentences: "We are just favoring and helping the thief...

Sentences_from: -- Poczekamy tutaj -- szepnął. -- Te kamienie na prawo stanowią wyborną osłonę.
Sentences_to: "This will do," said he. "These rocks upon the right make an admirable screen."
Translated_sentences: "We'll wait here," he whispered. "These stones to the right are an exquisite cover.

Sentences_from: Nie miałem tak miłego dnia od chwili, gdym pozwał sir Johna Morland o bezprawne polowanie w jego własnym lesie.
Sentences_to: I told the police last time they did it that they should stop these disgraceful exhibitions.
Translated_sentences: I had not had such a nice day since I sued Sir John Morland for unlawful hunting in his own forest.

Sentences_from: -- Widzę, że pan przejął się tą stratą.
Sentences_to: "I just don't attempt to explain it.
Translated_sentences: "I see that you are concerned about this loss.

Sentences_from: Pozostawało tylko sprawdzić, czy istotnie w owym czasie przedsięwzięła kroki rozwodowe.
Sentences_to: I could only check it by finding if she had, indeed, instituted divorce proceedings against her husband at or about the time of the tragedy.
Translated_sentences: All that remained was to see if she had indeed taken divorce at that time.

Sentences_from: Musisz chyba przyznać, że niema w tem nic nadnaturalnego.
Sentences_to: You must allow that there is nothing supernatural about this, at any rate?"
Translated_sentences: You must admit that there is nothing supernatural about it.

Sentences_from: -- Jeżeli widywał panią tak rzadko i otrzymywał od pani nieczęste listy, skądże mógł być do tego stopnia poinformowany o jej interesach, aby przychodzić jej z pomocą, jak to pani sama zeznała?
Sentences_to: "But if you saw him so seldom and wrote so seldom, how did he know enough about your affairs to be able to help you, as you say that he has done?"
Translated_sentences: "If he saw you so rarely and received infrequent letters from you, how could he have been so informed of her interests as to come to her aid, as you yourself testified?"

Sentences_from: Tajemniczy nieznajomy, nie mogąc sam mnie tropić, polecił to owemu chłopcu. Ten donosił mu zapewne o każdym moim kroku.
Sentences_to: Possibly I had taken no step since I had been upon the moor which had not been observed and reported. Always there was this feeling of an unseen force, a fine net drawn round us with infinite skill and delicacy, holding us so lightly that it was only at some supreme moment that one realized that one was indeed entangled in its meshes.
Translated_sentences: A mysterious stranger, unable to track me down himself, recommended it to the boy. He probably reported to him about my every step.

Sentences_from: -- Wszak pan wie, co mi polecił Holmes...
Sentences_to: "Well, you know what my instructions are.
Translated_sentences: "You know what Holmes told me...

Sentences_from: Widok był na trawnik przed portykiem.
Sentences_to: It opened upon the grassy space which lay in front of the hall door.
Translated_sentences: The view was on the lawn in front of the porter.

Sentences_from: Na pierwszej stronicy był nagłówek: „Baskerville Hall”, a pod spodem data: „1742”.
Sentences_to: At the head was written: "Baskerville Hall," and below in large, scrawling figures: "1742."
Translated_sentences: On the first page was the heading" Baskerville Hall, and underneath was the date" "1742."

Sentences_from: Z pośród wielu Mortimerów, jeden tylko mógł być tym, o którego nam chodziło.
Sentences_to: There were several Mortimers, but only one who could be our visitor.
Translated_sentences: Of the many Mortimers, only one could be the one we wanted.

Sentences_from: -- Pani się myli -- rzekłem. -- Jestem tylko jego przyjacielem.
Sentences_to: "No, no," said I. "Only a humble commoner, but his friend.
Translated_sentences: "You're wrong," I said. "I'm just his friend.

Sentences_from: -- On nie napadnie na żaden dom.
Sentences_to: "He'll break into no house, sir. I give you my solemn word upon that.
Translated_sentences: "He's not to attack any house.

Sentences_from: Rozległo się miarowe stąpanie. Kroki stawały się coraz głośniejsze i wyraźniejsze, dochodziły do nas przez mgłę, jak przez zasłonę, i oto nagle pojawił się ten, na którego czekaliśmy.
Sentences_to: So as the fog-bank flowed onward we fell back before it until we were half a mile from the house, and still that dense white sea, with the moon silvering its upper edge, swept slowly and inexorably on.
Translated_sentences: There was a steady treading. The footsteps became louder and clearer, they came to us through the fog, as if through a veil, and suddenly the one we were waiting for appeared.

Sentences_from: Nie myśl, że to było złudzenie zmysłów. O ile mogłem zauważyć, był to mężczyzna wysokiego wzrostu, szczupły.
Sentences_to: There, outlined as black as an ebony statue on that shining back-ground, I saw the figure of a man upon the tor.
Translated_sentences: Do not think that it was an illusion of the senses. As far as I could see, he was a tall man, slim.

Sentences_from: Jeśli nam się nie uda wyświetlić sprawy, cała odpowiedzialność spadnie na pana.
Sentences_to: Oh, Dr. Mortimer, Dr. Mortimer, to think that you should not have called me in! You have indeed much to answer for."
Translated_sentences: If we fail to display the case, all responsibility will fall on you.

Sentences_from: Usiadłem na łóżku i począłem nasłuchiwać.
Sentences_to: It was the sob of a woman, the muffled, strangling gasp of one who is torn by an uncontrollable sorrow. I sat up in bed and listened intently.
Translated_sentences: I sat down on the bed and began to listen.

Sentences_from: Możnaby sądzić, że taki maryaż powinien być mile widzianym przez Stapletona, jednak spostrzegam niezadowolenie na jego twarzy, ilekroć sir Henryk zbliża się do jego siostry, lub okazuje swój zachwyt. Tłómaczę to sobie egoistycznem przywiązaniem, bo życie przyrodnika na tem pustkowiu byłoby jeszcze smutniejsze, gdyby go nie opromieniała miss Beryl.
Sentences_to: They dine here to-night, and there is some talk of our going to them next week. One would imagine that such a match would be very welcome to Stapleton, and yet I have more than once caught a look of the strongest disapprobation in his face when Sir Henry has been paying some attention to his sister.
Translated_sentences: One might think that such a maryage should be welcomed by Stapleton, but I see dissatisfaction on his face whenever Sir Henry approaches his sister or shows his delight. I am arguing with selfish attachment, because the life of a naturalist in this wilderness would be even sadder if he had not been illuminated by Miss Beryl.

Sentences_from: Ten blady mężczyzna z czarną brodą wydawał mi się podejrzanym.
Sentences_to: Yet he had taken the obvious risk of discovery in declaring that it was not so. Why had he done this?
Translated_sentences: This pale man with a black beard seemed suspicious to me.

Sentences_from: Podniósł się trzymając w ręku stary but.
Sentences_to: He held an old black boot in the air.
Translated_sentences: He got up holding an old shoe in his hand.

Sentences_from: -- No i cóż, czy Seldon opuścił już te strony? -- rzekłem -- czy jeszcze grasuje?
Sentences_to: "Well," said I, "has this precious relation of yours departed, or is he still lurking out yonder?"
Translated_sentences: "Well, has Seldon left these pages yet?" "I said," is he still prowing?

Sentences_from: (To są przestrogi Hugona Baskerville, spisane dla jego synów, Rogera i Jana, z rozkazem, aby o tem wszystkiem nie wspominali swej siostrze, Elżbiecie).
Sentences_to: "[This from Hugo Baskerville to his sons Rodger and John, with instructions that they say nothing thereof to their sister Elizabeth.]"
Translated_sentences: (These are Hugo Baskerville's warnings, written for his sons, Roger and John, with the order not to mention all this to their sister, Elizabeth.)

Sentences_from: W oczach kobiety bywają błyski, wymowniejsze od słów.
Sentences_to: But he has never let us get together, and it was only to-day for the first time that I saw a chance of having a few words with her alone.
Translated_sentences: In the eyes of a woman there are flashes, more eloquent than words.

Sentences_from: Zdaje mi się, że ujrzał istotnie jakieś dziwne stworzenie w Alei Wiązów...
Sentences_to: I fancy that he really did see something of the kind upon that last night in the Yew Alley.
Translated_sentences: I think he did see some strange creature in The Alley of The Eims...

Sentences_from: Tam, w tej jaskini jest klucz do tajemnicy.
Sentences_to: There, in that hut upon the moor, seems to lie the very centre of that problem which has vexed me so sorely.
Translated_sentences: There, in this cave, is the key to the mystery.

Sentences_from: Przypuściwszy, że jakie nieszczęście spotka naszego przyjaciela -- daruj mi pan tę smutną hypotezę -- kto wówczas odziedziczy majątek?
Sentences_to: Supposing that anything happened to our young friend here--you will forgive the unpleasant hypothesis!--who would inherit the estate?"
Translated_sentences: Supposing that what misfortune would befall our friend -- forgive me this sad hypothesis -- who would then inherit the estate?

Sentences_from: Ten ostatni był niewielkiego wzrostu, silnie zbudowany, miał lat ze trzydzieści, włosy i oczy ciemne; gęste czarne brwi nadawały jego twarzy wyraz stanowczy, a nawet srogi. Z całej jego postawy i ogorzałego oblicza było znać, że dużo przebywał na świeżem powietrzu; wyglądał na skończonego gentlemana.
Sentences_to: The latter was a small, alert, dark-eyed man about thirty years of age, very sturdily built, with thick black eyebrows and a strong, pugnacious face. He wore a ruddy-tinted tweed suit and had the weather-beaten appearance of one who has spent most of his time in the open air, and yet there was something in his steady eye and the quiet assurance of his bearing which indicated the gentleman.
Translated_sentences: The latter was small in height, strongly built, he was thirty years old, his hair and eyes dark; thick black eyebrows gave his face a firm and even stern expression. From all his attitude and his hot face it was known that he was much in the fresh air; he looked like a finished gentleman.

Sentences_from: Nie było innej rady, jak go schwytać na gorącym uczynku, a w tym celu musiałem użyć sir Henryka, z narażeniem jego nerwów.
Sentences_to: There seemed to be no alternative but to catch him red-handed, and to do so we had to use Sir Henry, alone and apparently unprotected, as a bait. We did so, and at the cost of a severe shock to our client we succeeded in completing our case and driving Stapleton to his destruction.

Sentences_from: Gdyby mu dopomagał człowiek, moglibyśmy znaleźć dowody; ale choćbyśmy odszukali psa, nie pomoże nam zaciągnąć pętlicy na szyi swego pana.

Sentences_from: Z pańskich słów miarkuję, że ów młodzieniec jest równie bezpieczny w Londynie, jak i w Devonshire.

Sentences_from: -- Sądzę, że możemy posunąć się jeszcze dalej na drodze przypuszczeń. Ten dar został wręczony w chwili, gdy doktor Mortimer opuszczał szpital, aby rozpocząć praktykę na własną rękę.
Sentences_to: "I think that we might venture a little farther than this. Look at it in this light. On what occasion would it be most probable that such a presentation would be made? When would his friends unite to give him a pledge of their good will? Obviously at the moment when Dr. Mortimer withdrew from the service of the hospital in order to start in practice for himself. We know there has been a presentation. We believe there has been a change from a town hospital to a country practice. Is it, then, stretching our inference too far to say that the presentation was on the occasion of the change?"
Translated_sentences: "I think we can go even further in the way of conjecture. This gift was given the moment Dr. Mortimer left the hospital to begin practicing on his own.

Sentences_from: Gdy dorósł, wdał się w złe towarzystwo, zaczął hulać i jeszcze gorzej... Wpędził naszą biedną matkę do grobu, a nasze nazwisko błotem obryzgał.
Sentences_to: Then as he grew older he met wicked companions, and the devil entered into him until he broke my mother's heart and dragged our name in the dirt.

Sentences_from: Mówiłem ci już w Londynie, a teraz powtarzam, że nie miałem jeszcze tak groźnego przeciwnika.
