Translated_sentences: Be that as it may, it will be difficult for me now to carry out your command: that I should never abandon Sir Henry. I would have been quick to sleath to him if I had followed him like a shadow.

Sentences_from: Nagle odskoczyli od siebie. Spłoszył ich Stapleton.
Sentences_to: What all this meant I could not imagine, but I was deeply ashamed to have witnessed so intimate a scene without my friend's knowledge.
Translated_sentences: Suddenly, they jumped away from each other. They were scared off by Stapleton.

Sentences_from: Nie zdziwiłbym się, gdyby ten głos był wabieniem ostatniego bąka w Europie.
Sentences_to: Yes, I should not be surprised to learn that what we have heard is the cry of the last of the bitterns."
Translated_sentences: I would not be surprised if this voice were the lub of the last fart in Europe.

Sentences_from: Śmierć sir Karola pozostała niewyjaśniona; władze policyjne łamały sobie głowę nad jej przyczyną, okolica była w strachu, wreszcie oddano sprawę w nasze ręce.
Sentences_to: "So much for the death of Sir Charles Baskerville. You perceive the devilish cunning of it, for really it would be almost impossible to make a case against the real murderer.
Translated_sentences: Sir Charles' death remained unexplained; the police authorities were breaking their heads over its cause, the area was in fear, and finally the matter was put in our hands.

Sentences_from: Wiedziałem, że jest chory na serce i że ciągły niepokój źle wpływa na jego zdrowie.
Sentences_to: His heart was, I knew, affected, and the constant anxiety in which he lived, however chimerical the cause of it might be, was evidently having a serious effect upon his health.
Translated_sentences: I knew that he had heart disease and that constant anxiety was bad for his health.

Sentences_from: Barrymore, zaniósłszy kuferki do naszych pokojów, wrócił i stał przy drzwiach, jako wytrawny służbista, nie chcąc przerywać naszej rozmowy. Był to mężczyzna lat średnich, niezwykłej urody, o twarzy bladej, z dużą czarną brodą i regularnymi rysami.
Sentences_to: I saw his dark face lit up with a boyish enthusiasm as he gazed about him. The light beat upon him where he stood, but long shadows trailed down the walls and hung like a black canopy above him. Barrymore had returned from taking our luggage to our rooms. He stood in front of us now with the subdued manner of a well-trained servant. He was a remarkable-looking man, tall, handsome, with a square black beard and pale, distinguished features.
Translated_sentences: Barrymore, having carried the trunks to our rooms, returned and stood at the door as a seasoned servant, not wanting to interrupt our conversation. He was a man of medium years, of extraordinary beauty, with a pale face, with a large black beard and regular features.

Sentences_from: Przyznaję, że moja w tem wina: trzeba było poprowadzić sprawę inaczej i oszczędzić naszemu klientowi tej przykrości, ale nie mogłem przewidzieć, że ten łotr posmaruje psa siarką i że owej nocy będzie mgła, dzięki czemu sir Henryk nie mógł widzieć z oddali czworonożnego sprzymierzeńca Stapletona, który wyskoczył znienacka i przestraszył tego odważnego człowieka.
Sentences_to: That Sir Henry should have been exposed to this is, I must confess, a reproach to my management of the case, but we had no means of foreseeing the terrible and paralyzing spectacle which the beast presented, nor could we predict the fog which enabled him to burst upon us at such short notice. We succeeded in our object at a cost which both the specialist and Dr. Mortimer assure me will be a temporary one.
Translated_sentences: I admit that it was my fault: it was necessary to conduct the matter differently and spare our client this annoyance, but I could not have foreseen that this thief would smear the dog with sulfur and that there would be fog that night, so that Sir Henry could not see from a distance the four-legged ally Stapleton, who jumped out suddenly and frightened this brave man.

Sentences_from: -- Mieszkam tu od lat dwóch zaledwie.
Sentences_to: "I have only been here two years.
Translated_sentences: "I've only lived here for two years.

Sentences_from: -- Ale czy można być pewnym, że przed wyjazdem nie wyrządzi krzywdy nikomu?
Sentences_to: "But how about the chance of his holding someone up before he goes?"
Translated_sentences: "But can you be sure that he won't hurt anyone before leaving?"

Sentences_from: W jaki sposób byłby się upomniał o spadek, bez zwrócenia podejrzeń?
Sentences_to: How could he claim it without causing suspicion and inquiry?"
Translated_sentences: How would he claim to be an inheritance without returning the suspicions?

Sentences_from: -- Spodziewam się, że już go tu niema; nie dawał znaku życia od dnia, gdy po raz ostatni zaniosłem mu żywność.
Sentences_to: "I don't know, sir. I hope to heaven that he has gone, for he has brought nothing but trouble here! I've not heard of him since I left out food for him last, and that was three days ago."
Translated_sentences: "I expect it's gone; he hadn't given a sign of life since the last time I brought him food.

Sentences_from: -- Może tak światło umieścił, że widać je tylko z tego punktu.
Sentences_to: "It may be so placed as to be only visible from here."
Translated_sentences: "Maybe he put the light so that you can only see it from this point.

Sentences_from: Prawo jest po jego stronie. Lyons każdej chwili może zażądać, abym z nim żyła.
Sentences_to: The law is upon his side, and every day I am faced by the possibility that he may force me to live with him.
Translated_sentences: The law is on his side. Lyons can request that I live with him at any time.

Sentences_from: Jako Stapleton, z resztkami ukradzionych pieniędzy, z pięknymi zbiorami entomologicznymi przesiedlił się do Anglii południowej.
Sentences_to: I learned at the British Museum that he was a recognized authority upon the subject, and that the name of Vandeleur has been permanently attached to a certain moth which he had, in his Yorkshire days, been the first to describe.
Translated_sentences: As Stapleton, with the remnants of stolen money, with beautiful entomological collections, he resettleed to southern England.

Sentences_from: Ten łotr był synem Rogera Baskerville, młodszego brata sir Karola; wywędrował do Ameryki z bardzo złą reputacyą.
Sentences_to: He did, as a matter of fact, marry, and had one child, this fellow, whose real name is the same as his father's.
Translated_sentences: This thief was the son of Roger Baskerville, sir Charles' younger brother; he went to America with a very bad reputation.

Sentences_from: Mówił to lekko, ale patrzał na siostrę badawczo i groźnie.
Sentences_to: He spoke unconcernedly, but his small light eyes glanced incessantly from the girl to me.
Translated_sentences: He said it lightly, but he looked at his sister in a research and threatening way.

Sentences_from: -- Tak. Sir Karol lubił mówić o rozporządzeniach, zawartych w swoim testamencie.
Sentences_to: "Yes; Sir Charles was very fond of talking about the provisions of his will."
Translated_sentences: Yes. Sir Charles liked to talk about the ordinances contained in his will.

Sentences_from: -- A zatem i pan skłaniasz się do nadprzyrodzonych wyjaśnień...
Sentences_to: "Then you are yourself inclining to the supernatural explanation."
Translated_sentences: "So you are also inclined to supernatural explanations...

Sentences_from: Jeżeli ma go opuścić, to on, Stapleton, woli, żeby poślubiła sąsiada, mieszkającego tak blizko, niż kogokolwiek innego. Ale musi oswoić się z tą myślą.
Sentences_to: If she had to leave him he had rather it was to a neighbour like myself than to anyone else. But in any case it was a blow to him, and it would take him some time before he could prepare himself to meet it.
Translated_sentences: If she is to leave him, he, Stapleton, prefers her to marry a neighbor who lives so nicely than anyone else. But he must get used to this thought.

Sentences_from: Jak znajdujesz: czy mógłbym być dobrym mężem dla kobiety ukochanej?
Sentences_to: Tell me straight, now! Is there anything that would prevent me from making a good husband to a woman that I loved?"
Translated_sentences: How do you find: could I be a good husband to a beloved woman?

Sentences_from: Ponieważ się spóźniał, wyszedłem na jego spotkanie i wtedy usłyszałem okrzyk...
Sentences_to: When he did not come I was surprised, and I naturally became alarmed for his safety when I heard cries upon the moor.
Translated_sentences: Because he was late, I went out to meet him and then I heard a shout...

Sentences_from: Przez chwilę siedziałem z zapartym oddechem, oczom własnym nie wierząc, wreszcie odzyskałem głos, powróciła mi przytomność, a jednocześnie spadł z serca kamień odpowiedzialności.
Sentences_to: For a moment or two I sat breathless, hardly able to believe my ears. Then my senses and my voice came back to me, while a crushing weight of responsibility seemed in an instant to be lifted from my soul.
Translated_sentences: For a moment I sat with my breath constipated, not believing my eyes, finally I regained my voice, my consciousness returned, and at the same time a stone of responsibility fell from my heart.

Sentences_from: Przed wieczorem będziemy wiedzieli, czy Barrymore jest na swojem stanowisku w Devonshire.
Sentences_to: That should let us know before evening whether Barrymore is at his post in Devonshire or not."
Translated_sentences: Before evening we will know if Barrymore is in his post in Devonshire.

Sentences_from: -- Wiem, bo na własne oczy widziałem tego, który mu nosi prowianty.
Sentences_to: "I know it because I have seen with my own eyes the messenger who takes him his food."
Translated_sentences: "I know, because I saw with my own eyes the one who carries his provisions.

Sentences_from: -- Co to znaczy, Perkins? -- spytał znowu doktor Mortimer.
Sentences_to: "What is this, Perkins?" asked Dr. Mortimer.
Translated_sentences: "What does that mean, Perkins?" Dr. Mortimer asked again.

Sentences_from: Wszyscy mówią, że był to pies ogromny, przezroczysty.
Sentences_to: They all agreed that it was a huge creature, luminous, ghastly, and spectral.
Translated_sentences: Everyone says that it was a huge, transparent dog.

Sentences_from: „Miał jechać do Londynu z mojej porady.
Sentences_to: "It was at my advice that Sir Charles was about to go to London.
Translated_sentences: "He was supposed to go to London on my advice.

Sentences_from: Taka czaszka byłaby ozdobą każdego muzeum.
Sentences_to: A cast of your skull, sir, until the original is available, would be an ornament to any anthropological museum.
Translated_sentences: Such a skull would be the decoration of any museum.

Sentences_from: Stapleton postarał się o but sir Henryka, aby w razie danym wyzyskać węch psa i wprowadzić go na trop ofiary.
Sentences_to: By chance, however, the first boot which was procured for him was a new one and, therefore, useless for his purpose.
Translated_sentences: Stapleton took care of Sir Henry's shoe in order to exploit the dog's s snot and lead him to the victim's trail if given.

Sentences_from: Dostarczał mi pożywienia i czystej bielizny.
Sentences_to: I was dependent upon him for food and clean linen.
Translated_sentences: He provided me with food and clean underwear.

Sentences_from: Sir Karol był skryty, małomówny. Zbliżyliśmy się z powodu jego choroby, przytem łączyły nas wspólne upodobania naukowe.
Sentences_to: Sir Charles was a retiring man, but the chance of his illness brought us together, and a community of interests in science kept us so.
Translated_sentences: Sir Charles was secretive, taciturn. We became closer because of his illness, and we shared a common scientific taste.

Sentences_from: -- Dla bardzo prostej przyczyny, że mam tego psa przed oczyma; stoi za temi drzwiami, a jego właściciel w tej chwili właśnie do nich dzwoni.
Sentences_to: "For the very simple reason that I see the dog himself on our very door-step, and there is the ring of its owner.
Translated_sentences: "For the very simple reason that I have this dog in front of my eyes; he is standing behind this door, and his owner is calling them at the moment.

Sentences_from: Badacze kryminologii pamiętają podobny wypadek w roku 1866 w Grodnie, a drugi w północnej Karolinie w roku 1878, ale obecny fakt ma swoje odrębności. I teraz nawet, po wykryciu szczegółów, nie wiem jeszcze, w jaki sposób Stapleton przyczynił się do śmierci sir Karola.
Sentences_to: Students of criminology will remember the analogous incidents in Godno, in Little Russia, in the year '66, and of course there are the Anderson murders in North Carolina, but this case possesses some features which are entirely its own. Even now we have no clear case against this very wily man.
Translated_sentences: Criminology researchers remember a similar accident in 1866 in Grodno and another in North Carolina in 1878, but the present fact has its own differences. And now, even after the details have been discovered, I do not yet know how Stapleton contributed to sir Charles' death.

Sentences_from: Naraziło mnie to na dużą stratę pieniężną; ale żal mi tylko zmarłych dzieci; dla siebie nie żałuję tego, bo mam czas oddawać się moim ulubionym badaniom i znalazłem tu obfite pole do studyów nad botaniką i zoologią. Siostra dzieli moje upodobania przyrodnicze.
Sentences_to: And yet, if it were not for the loss of the charming companionship of the boys, I could rejoice over my own misfortune, for, with my strong tastes for botany and zoology, I find an unlimited field of work here, and my sister is as devoted to Nature as I am.
Translated_sentences: This exposed me to a large monetary loss; but I feel sorry only for the dead children; for myself I do not regret it, because I have time to indulge in my favorite research and I found here an abundant field for studying botany and zoology. My sister shares my natural tastes.

Sentences_from: Przekonywam się coraz bardziej, że jesteś pan szpiegowany tutaj, a wśród milionów ludzi, nagromadzonych w stolicy, trudno jest wykryć tych pańskich prześladowców, czy opiekunów.
Sentences_to: I have ample evidence that you are being dogged in London, and amid the millions of this great city it is difficult to discover who these people are or what their object can be.
Translated_sentences: I am becoming more and more convinced that you are being spied on here, and among the millions of people who have accumulated in the capital, it is difficult to detect your persecutors or guardians.

Sentences_from: W dzisiejszej epoce parweniuszów miło jest widzieć potomka starożytnego a podupadłego rodu, odzyskującego fortunę swych przodków i przywracającego świetność staremu nazwisku.
Sentences_to: More wise than those who go on until the wheel turns against them, he realized his gains and returned to England with them. It is only two years since he took up his residence at Baskerville Hall, and it is common talk how large were those schemes of reconstruction and improvement which have been interrupted by his death.
Translated_sentences: In today's era of parvenus, it is nice to see a descendant of an ancient and deteriorated family, regaining the fortune of his ancestors and restoring the splendor of the old name.

Sentences_from: Upadał coraz niżej, wreszcie spełnił tę ostatnią zbrodnię... Ale dla mnie jest on zawsze małym chłopaczkiem z jasnymi kędziorami, którego niańczyłam, jako starsza siostra.
Sentences_to: From crime to crime he sank lower and lower, until it is only the mercy of God which has snatched him from the scaffold; but to me, sir, he was always the little curly-headed boy that I had nursed and played with, as an elder sister would.
Translated_sentences: He fell lower and lower, finally fulfilled this last crime... But to me, he's always a little boy with bright little ones, whom I nanned as an older sister.

Sentences_from: Są poszlaki, że już był wylękniony, zanim począł uciekać.
Sentences_to: There are indications that the man was crazed with fear before ever he began to run."
Translated_sentences: There is circumstantial evidence that he was already fearful before he began to flee.

Sentences_from: Patrząc przez okno na te bagna, usiane kamieniami, zastanawiałem się, co mogło skłonić tak wykształconego mężczyznę i tak piękną kobietę do obrania tutaj siedziby.
Sentences_to: As I looked from their windows at the interminable granite-flecked moor rolling unbroken to the farthest horizon I could not but marvel at what could have brought this highly educated man and this beautiful woman to live in such a place.
Translated_sentences: Looking out the window at these swamps, strewn with stones, I wondered what might have prompted such an educated man and such a beautiful woman to choose a residence here.

Sentences_from: Przywiózł wiele ciekawych wiadomości z Afryki Południowej. Spędziliśmy niejeden miły wieczór na rozprawach o anatomii porównawczej.
Sentences_to: He had brought back much scientific information from South Africa, and many a charming evening we have spent together discussing the comparative anatomy of the Bushman and the Hottentot.
Translated_sentences: He brought a lot of interesting news from South Africa. We spent many a nice evening at dissertations on comparative anatomy.

Sentences_from: Dotychczas jednak nie przywiązywałem wagi do tej legendy.
Sentences_to: It's the pet story of the family, though I never thought of taking it seriously before.
Translated_sentences: So far, however, I have not attached importance to this legend.

Sentences_from: Ten widok pozbawił go przytomności, bo inaczej nie byłby uciekał w stronę przeciwną, zamiast biedz ku pałacowi.
Sentences_to: If that were so, and it seems most probable, only a man who had lost his wits would have run from the house instead of towards it.
Translated_sentences: This sight deprived him of consciousness, otherwise he would not have fled in the opposite direction, instead of poor people towards the palace.

Sentences_from: Słońce już było na zachodzie, gdym doszedł do szczytu góry.
Sentences_to: As I approached the hut, walking as warily as Stapleton would do when with poised net he drew near the settled butterfly, I satisfied myself that the place had indeed been used as a habitation.
Translated_sentences: The sun was already in the west when I reached the top of the mountain.

Sentences_from: A teraz, Watson, sądzę, że nic nam nie pozostaje, jak odwiedzić twoją znajomą, panią Laurę Lyons.
Sentences_to: Now, Watson, I think that we cannot employ our time better than by calling upon your acquaintance, Mrs. Laura Lyons."
Translated_sentences: And now, Watson, I think we have nothing left but to visit your friend, Mrs. Laura Lyons.

Sentences_from: -- Widzę, że możnaby galopować po tej równinie.
Sentences_to: "It would be a rare place for a gallop."
Translated_sentences: "I see that you could gallop on this plain.

Sentences_from: A więc sądziłeś, że to ja jestem zbrodniarzem?
Sentences_to: So you actually thought that I was the criminal?"
Translated_sentences: So you thought I was the criminal?

Sentences_from: -- Myślałem o niej dużo. Jest istotnie dziwna.
Sentences_to: "Yes, I have thought a good deal of it in the course of the day."
Translated_sentences: "I thought a lot about her. It is indeed strange.

Sentences_from: -- I niewątpliwie zaglądałeś pod wszystkie kamienie, zanim natrafiłeś na moją kryjówkę?
Sentences_to: "And have no doubt searched all the huts until you came to this one?"
Translated_sentences: And you must have looked under all the stones before you came across my hiding place?"

Sentences_from: -- Dobrze, odpowiem -- rzekła. -- O co panu chodzi?
Sentences_to: "Well, I'll answer," she said. "What are your questions?"
Translated_sentences: "Okay, I'll answer," she said. "What do you mean?"

Sentences_from: Klucz zazgrzytał w zamku, po chwili doszedł mnie dziwny odgłos, jakby warczenia.
Sentences_to: A key turned in a lock, and as he passed in there was a curious scuffling noise from within.
Translated_sentences: The key grinded in the lock, after a while I heard a strange sound, like growling.

Sentences_from: Cała równina była pogrążona w ciszy grobowej.
Sentences_to: A vague pathway among the boulders led to the dilapidated opening which served as a door.
Translated_sentences: The whole plain was immersed in the silence of the grave.

Sentences_from: Odczytaj je pani, a przekonasz się, czy odpowiadają wyglądowi pana Stapleton i jego domniemanej siostry.
Sentences_to: Read them and see if you can doubt the identity of these people."
Translated_sentences: Read them to you and you will see if they correspond to the appearance of Mr. Stapleton and his alleged sister.

Sentences_from: Nie wiesz zapewne, doktorze Mortimer, że śledzono panów dzisiaj, gdyście wyszli z domu?
Sentences_to: You did not know, Dr. Mortimer, that you were followed this morning from my house?"
Translated_sentences: Don't you know, Dr. Mortimer, that you were followed today when you left the house?

Sentences_from: Wiem, jak ci jest obojętnem, czy ziemia obraca się dokoła słońca, czy też dzieje się odwrotnie.
Sentences_to: I can still remember your complete indifference as to whether the sun moved round the earth or the earth round the sun.
Translated_sentences: I know how indifferent it is to you whether the earth revolves around the sun or the other way around.

Sentences_from: -- Nie, to mój przyjaciel, doktor Watson.
Sentences_to: "No, this is my friend Dr. Watson."
Translated_sentences: "No, that's my friend, Dr. Watson.

Sentences_from: -- Jeżeli nie wyjdzie za kwadrans, cała robota na nic.
Sentences_to: "If he isn't out in a quarter of an hour the path will be covered.
Translated_sentences: "If it doesn't come out in a quarter of an hour, all the work is for nothing.

Sentences_from: Do uszu jej doszła wieść o nagłej śmierci zbiegłego więźnia na moczarach, a że wiedziała, iż pies trzymany jest tam na uwięzi, domyśliła się, jaką śmierć Stapleton gotuje sir Henrykowi, tembardziej, gdy mąż przyprowadził psa i zamknął go w oficynie.
Sentences_to: She had learned something of the death of the convict, and she knew that the hound was being kept in the out-house on the evening that Sir Henry was coming to dinner. She taxed her husband with his intended crime, and a furious scene followed, in which he showed her for the first time that she had a rival in his love.
Translated_sentences: She heard the news of the sudden death of an escaped prisoner in the swamp, and since she knew that the dog was being tethered there, she guessed what kind of death Stapleton was preparing for Sir Henry, even more so when her husband brought the dog and locked it in the outbuilding.

Sentences_from: -- A teraz, zechciej mi pan powiedzieć, doktorze Mortimer -- będzie to szczegół ważny -- czy ślady, któreś pan spostrzegł, pozostały na żwirze, czy na trawie?
Sentences_to: "Now, tell me, Dr. Mortimer--and this is important--the marks which you saw were on the path and not on the grass?"
Translated_sentences: "Now, tell me, Dr. Mortimer -- this will be an important detail -- did the marks you notice remain on the gravel or on the grass?"

Sentences_from: Cały dom spowity w gęstą mgłę; to się podnosi, to opada, ukazując łąkę i trzęsawisko.
Sentences_to: The house is banked in with rolling clouds, which rise now and then to show the dreary curves of the moor, with thin, silver veins upon the sides of the hills, and the distant boulders gleaming where the light strikes upon their wet faces.
Translated_sentences: The whole house shrouded in dense fog; it rises, it falls, showing a meadow and a bog.

Sentences_from: -- Nie mogę ich zapomnieć, miss Stapleton -- odparłem. -- Jestem przyjacielem sir Henryka, chodzi mi o jego bezpieczeństwo.
Sentences_to: "But I can't forget them, Miss Stapleton," said I. "I am Sir Henry's friend, and his welfare is a very close concern of mine.
Translated_sentences: "I can't forget them, Miss Stapleton," I said. "I am a friend of Sir Henry, I mean his safety.

Sentences_from: Słuchaj, Barrymore -- rzekł -- postanowiliśmy obaj zmusić cię do powiedzenia prawdy. Im prędzej ją wyznasz, tem lepiej dla ciebie.
Sentences_to: "Look here, Barrymore," said Sir Henry, sternly; "we have made up our minds to have the truth out of you, so it will save you trouble to tell it sooner rather than later.
Translated_sentences: Look, Barrymore -- he said -- we both decided to get you to tell the truth. The sooner you confess it, the better for you.

Sentences_from: -- Sługami Dyabła mogą być ludzie z krwi i kości.
Sentences_to: "The devil's agents may be of flesh and blood, may they not?
Translated_sentences: "The servants of the Dyab can be flesh-and-blood people.

Sentences_from: Pokój był rodzajem muzeum; w gablotach i na ścianach były rozpięte rzadkie okazy motylów.
Sentences_to: The room had been fashioned into a small museum, and the walls were lined by a number of glass-topped cases full of that collection of butterflies and moths the formation of which had been the relaxation of this complex and dangerous man.
Translated_sentences: The room was a kind of museum; in the showcases and on the walls were stretched rare specimens of butterflies.

Sentences_from: Nasz przyjazd był widocznie wypadkiem dnia, gdyż obstąpili nas tragarze, a naczelnik stacyi ze swoim sztabem przyglądali nam się ciekawie.
Sentences_to: It was a sweet, simple country spot, but I was surprised to observe that by the gate there stood two soldierly men in dark uniforms, who leaned upon their short rifles and glanced keenly at us as we passed. The coachman, a hard-faced, gnarled little fellow, saluted Sir Henry Baskerville, and in a few minutes we were flying swiftly down the broad, white road.
Translated_sentences: Our arrival was apparently an accident of the day, because we were besiegeed by porters, and the head of the station with his staff watched us interestingly.

Sentences_from: Wypraw do mnie depeszę przed wieczorem na Baker Street.
Sentences_to: Let me have a report by wire at Baker Street before evening.
Translated_sentences: I send a message to me before the evening on Baker Street.

Sentences_from: -- A nie widziałeś go już potem?
Sentences_to: "I see. And you saw no more of him?"
Translated_sentences: "And you didn't see him again?"

Sentences_from: -- Chcesz pan powiedzieć, że wchodzi to w zakres rzeczy nadprzyrodzonych?
Sentences_to: "You mean that the thing is supernatural?"
Translated_sentences: "Are you saying that this is within the scope of supernatural things?"

Translated_sentences: Well, there is nothing easier than to track down a teacher.

Sentences_from: Doktor Mortimer podsunął manuskrypt pod światło i głosem dobitnym czytał, co następuje:
Sentences_to: Dr. Mortimer turned the manuscript to the light and read in a high, cracking voice the following curious, old-world narrative:--
Translated_sentences: Dr. Mortimer put the manuscript under the light and read the following in an emphatic voice:

Sentences_from: Było to coś więcej. Do pokoju wszedł dorożkarz we własnej osobie.
Sentences_to: The ring at the bell proved to be something even more satisfactory than an answer, however, for the door opened and a rough-looking fellow entered who was evidently the man himself.
Translated_sentences: It was more than that. A cab driver himself entered the room.

Sentences_from: Nie! trzeba ich zatrzymać, ale nie spuszczać z nich oka.
Sentences_to: No, no, we will preserve them upon our list of suspects.
Translated_sentences: No! you have to stop them, but do not take your eye off them.

Sentences_from: Fakty następnych dni pozostały tak żywo w mojej pamięci, że mogę je opowiedzieć bez zaglądania do notatek.
Sentences_to: The incidents of the next few days are indelibly graven upon my recollection, and I can tell them without reference to the notes made at the time.
Translated_sentences: The facts of the following days remained so vivid in my memory that I can tell them without looking at my notes.

Sentences_from: -- Czy nie miał pan jakiej niespodzianki?
Sentences_to: "Well, it depends upon what you think worth reporting."
Translated_sentences: "Didn't you have a surprise?"

Sentences_from: -- A więc moje listy były niepotrzebne?
Sentences_to: "Then my reports have all been wasted!"--My voice trembled as I recalled the pains and the pride with which I had composed them.
Translated_sentences: "So my letters were unnecessary?"

Sentences_from: -- Wychodź, a proszę cię, bądź ostrożny z rewolwerem.
Sentences_to: "Come out," said he, "and please be careful with the revolver."
Translated_sentences: "Come out, and please be careful with your revolver.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli jest nieobecny, proszę odesłać depeszę sir Henrykowi Baskerville, Northumberland Hotel”.
Sentences_to: If absent, please return wire to Sir Henry Baskerville, Northumberland Hotel.'
Translated_sentences: If he is absent, please send the cable back to Sir Henry Baskerville, Northumberland Hotel."

Sentences_from: -- Nie wierzę w te brednie.
Sentences_to: "I do not believe in such nonsense."
Translated_sentences: "I don't believe this nonsense.

Sentences_from: Gardło miała sine i ślady paznogci na twarzy i ciele.
Sentences_to: As her beautiful head fell upon her chest I saw the clear red weal of a whiplash across her neck.
Translated_sentences: Her throat was blue and there were marks of nail on her face and body.

Sentences_from: -- Ani jednego -- same tylko przypuszczenia i wnioski.
Sentences_to: "Not a shadow of one--only surmise and conjecture.
Translated_sentences: -- Not one -- mere conjectures and conclusions.

Sentences_from: Odpocząwszy, wstawaliśmy, aby wracać do domu, bośmy już zaniechali dalszego pościgu.
Sentences_to: We had risen from our rocks and were turning to go home, having abandoned the hopeless chase.
Translated_sentences: After resting, we got up to go home, because we had already given up further pursuit.

Sentences_from: Holmes schylił się, aby go podnieść, przyczem pośliznęła mu się noga; gdybyśmy go nie podtrzymali, byłby wpadł w to błoto bezdenne.
Sentences_to: From amid a tuft of cotton grass which bore it up out of the slime some dark thing was projecting. Holmes sank to his waist as he stepped from the path to seize it, and had we not been there to drag him out he could never have set his foot upon firm land again.
Translated_sentences: Holmes folded down to pick him up, his leg slipping; if we hadn't sustained him, he would have fallen into this bottomless mud.

Sentences_from: Znajdziesz moje poglądy pod literą _B_ w moich aktach kryminalnych.
Sentences_to: You will find a few notes upon the matter under the heading B in my indexed list of cases."
Translated_sentences: You will find my views under the letter _B_ in my criminal records.

Sentences_from: Nagle wydał okrzyk zdziwienia. Podbiegł do łóżka, schylił się i z pod nocnej szafki wydobył but żółty.
Sentences_to: We had risen to depart when Baskerville gave a cry, of triumph, and diving into one of the corners of the room he drew a brown boot from under a cabinet.
Translated_sentences: Suddenly, he gave a cry of surprise. He ran to the bed, down and pulled out a yellow shoe from under the bedside table.

Sentences_from: Jeden krok fałszywy, a śmierć pewna.
Sentences_to: "A false step yonder means death to man or beast.
Translated_sentences: One step is false and death is certain.

Sentences_from: -- O ile zrozumiałem, jest wejście przez furtkę?
Sentences_to: "I understand that the yew hedge is penetrated at one point by a gate?"
Translated_sentences: "As far as I understand, is there an entrance through the gate?"

Sentences_from: Przed nami stał wystraszony posługacz, Niemiec.
Sentences_to: An agitated German waiter had appeared upon the scene.
Translated_sentences: In front of us stood a frightened servant, a German.

Sentences_from: Nauczę tych magnatów, że nie wolno im pozbawiać zwykłych śmiertelników tego, co im się słusznie należy.
Sentences_to: I am proud to say that I had no interest in the matter. I act entirely from a sense of public duty.
Translated_sentences: I will teach these magnates that they must not deprive mere mortals of what they are rightly entitled to.

Sentences_from: -- Nie wątpię o tem -- rzekł Holmes. -- Ale, prawda, zapomniałem panu powiedzieć, żeśmy go już opłakali. Byliśmy pewni, że to pan umarł.
Sentences_to: "I have no doubt that you would have had a more lively evening," said Holmes drily. "By the way, I don't suppose you appreciate that we have been mourning over you as having broken your neck?"
Translated_sentences: "I have no doubt about that," said Holmes. "But, true, I forgot to tell you that we were already mourning him. We were sure that you had died.

Sentences_from: Ponieważ wszystkie te pokoje są nieumeblowane, przeto cel wędrówki stawał się jeszcze bardziej zagadkowym. Światło błyszczało stale w jednym punkcie.
Sentences_to: When I came round the balcony he had reached the end of the farther corridor, and I could see from the glimmer of light through an open door that he had entered one of the rooms.
Translated_sentences: Since all these rooms are unfurnished, the purpose of the journey became even more puzzling. The light shone constantly at one point.

Sentences_from: -- Bo w razie przeciwnym nie wstrzymałbyś się od komunikowania się ze mną; zechciałbyś mnie zaopatrywać w lepsze jadło, cieplejszą odzież i wprowadziłbyś tamtych na mój ślad.
Sentences_to: "For you to know could not have helped us, and might possibly have led to my discovery. You would have wished to tell me something, or in your kindness you would have brought me out some comfort or other, and so an unnecessary risk would be run.
Translated_sentences: "Otherwise you wouldn't refrain from communicating with me; You would like to provide me with better food, warmer clothing, and you would put those on my track.

Sentences_from: Pies biegł trawnikiem, baronet aleją żwirową; dlatego pozostały tylko ślady jego kroków.
Sentences_to: On seeing him lying still the creature had probably approached to sniff at him, but finding him dead had turned away again.
Translated_sentences: The dog ran along the lawn, the baronet along a gravel alley; therefore, only traces of his steps remained.

Sentences_from: Jest siedemdziesiąt pięć gatunków perfum, które każdy detektyw powinien rozróżniać; wiele wypadków zależy od szybkiego poznawania perfum. Jaśmin naprowadził mnie na domysł, że list został przesłany przez kobietę.
Sentences_to: There are seventy-five perfumes, which it is very necessary that a criminal expert should be able to distinguish from each other, and cases have more than once within my own experience depended upon their prompt recognition.
Translated_sentences: There are seventy-five species of perfume that every detective should distinguish; many accidents depend on getting to know perfume quickly. Jasmine led me to speculate that the letter had been sent by a woman.

Sentences_from: -- Ale czemuż ukrywałeś się przedemną?
Sentences_to: "But why keep me in the dark?"
Translated_sentences: "But why were you hiding from me?"

Sentences_from: Czy dowiedział się, co on tu robi?
Sentences_to: Did he find out where he hid, or what he was doing?"
Translated_sentences: Did he find out what he was doing here?

Sentences_from: Taką laskę staroświecką, mocną, zapewniającą bezpieczeństwo, zwykli nosić starzy lekarze.
Sentences_to: It was just such a stick as the old-fashioned family practitioner used to carry--dignified, solid, and reassuring.
Translated_sentences: Such an old-fashioned, strong, safety-providing chick used to be worn by old doctors.

Sentences_from: -- Wynosimy się stąd, Elizo -- oznajmił jej kamerdyner. -- Pakuj nasze rzeczy.
Sentences_to: "We have to go, Eliza. This is the end of it. You can pack our things," said the butler.
Translated_sentences: "We're leaving here, Elizo," her butler said. "Pack our stuff.

Sentences_from: Jeden z pokojów na górze był zamknięty na klucz.
Sentences_to: On the upper floor, however, one of the bedroom doors was locked.
Translated_sentences: One of the rooms upstairs was locked.

Sentences_from: Doktor Mortimer spojrzał na Holmesa z zaciekawieniem; sir Henryk był widocznie zdziwiony.
Sentences_to: Dr. Mortimer looked at Holmes with an air of professional interest, and Sir Henry Baskerville turned a pair of puzzled dark eyes upon me.
Translated_sentences: Dr. Mortimer looked at Holmes with curiosity; Sir Henry was apparently astonished.

Sentences_from: „Pomiędzy innemi dotychczas nie wyjaśniono jednego faktu, wynikającego z zeznań Barrymora, a mianowicie, że ślady kroków jego pana zmieniły się z chwilą, gdy stał przy furtce i że odtąd szedł na palcach. „Niejaki Murphy, cygan, handlujący końmi, znajdował się wówczas na łące, w pewnej odległości od nieboszczyka, ale sam przyznaje, że był pijany.
Sentences_to: "I must thank you," said Sherlock Holmes, "for calling my attention to a case which certainly presents some features of interest.
Translated_sentences: "Among the others, one fact has not yet been clarified, resulting from Barrymor's testimony, namely, that the traces of his master's steps changed the moment he stood at the gate and that he was henceforth walking on tiptoes." A certain Murphy, a gypsy who traded in horses, was in a meadow at the time, some distance from the deceased, but he admits that he was drunk.

Sentences_from: Ta sprawa kosztowała mnie dwieście funtów, ale ją wygrałem, bo na podstawie starych akt dowiodłem, iż ta część lasu należy do włościan.
Sentences_to: The County Constabulary is in a scandalous state, sir, and it has not afforded me the protection to which I am entitled.
Translated_sentences: This case cost me two hundred pounds, but I won it, because on the basis of old records I proved that this part of the forest belongs to the states.

Sentences_from: Rozwiązałem je -- był tam bochenek chleba, wędzony ozór i dwa słoiki owocowych konserwów.
Sentences_to: It contained a loaf of bread, a tinned tongue, and two tins of preserved peaches.
Translated_sentences: I untied them -- there was a loaf of bread, a smoked tongue, and two jars of canned fruit.

Sentences_from: -- Widzisz -- mówił -- oto łąka, a to -- Baskerville Hall.
Sentences_to: "Very large." He unrolled one section and held it over his knee. "Here you have the particular district which concerns us. That is Baskerville Hall in the middle."
Translated_sentences: "You see," he said, "this is a meadow, and this is "Baskerville Hall."

Sentences_from: Lecz gdy chcesz mnie wywieść w pole, radzę ci używać innych papierosów, bo ilekroć ujrzę munsztuk z marką fabryczną Broadley, Oxford-Street, zawsze się domyślę, iż mój przyjaciel Watson jest w pobliżu.
Sentences_to: If you seriously desire to deceive me you must change your tobacconist; for when I see the stub of a cigarette marked Bradley, Oxford Street, I know that my friend Watson is in the neighbourhood. You will see it there beside the path.
Translated_sentences: But when you want to take me out into the field, I advise you to use other cigarettes, because whenever I see a munsztuk with the Broadley factory brand, Oxford-Street, I will always guess that my friend Watson is nearby.

Sentences_from: Stracił zaufanie do żony od chwili, gdy nie chciała mu pomagać w nastawianiu sideł na sir Karola.
Sentences_to: Stapleton's first idea was that this young stranger from Canada might possibly be done to death in London without coming down to Devonshire at all.
Translated_sentences: He had lost confidence in his wife from the moment she refused to help him set the snares on Sir Charles.

Sentences_from: -- Jeżeliś go nie widział, to skądże wiesz, że był na strychu?
Sentences_to: "If you didn't see him, how do you know he was in the loft?"
Translated_sentences: "If you haven't seen him, how do you know he was in the attic?"

Sentences_from: Wydawała się, jakby cudownem, nadprzyrodzonem zjawiskiem na tle ponurego krajobrazu.
Sentences_to: Her eyes were on her brother as I turned, and then she quickened her pace towards me.
Translated_sentences: It seemed like a miraculous, supernatural phenomenon against the backdrop of a gloomy landscape.

Sentences_from: -- Nic jeszcze nie rozumiem; bądź co bądź, to dziwne, jak wszystko, co się panu przytrafia od chwili powrotu do kraju. Ale mamy już kilka nici w ręku i spodziewam się, że nie ta, to druga, doprowadzi nas do wykrycia prawdy.
Sentences_to: "What do you make of it yourself?"
Translated_sentences: I don't understand anything yet; after all, it is strange how everything that has happened to you since you returned to the country. But we already have a few threads in our hands, and I expect that not this one, it is the second, will lead us to the discovery of the truth.

Sentences_from: Czy możesz pan wstać o własnej sile?
Sentences_to: Are you strong enough to stand?"
Translated_sentences: Can you stand up on your own?

Sentences_from: -- Ja słyszałem płacz najwyraźniej i mógłbym ręczyć, że płakała kobieta.
Sentences_to: "I heard it distinctly, and I am sure that it was really the sob of a woman."
Translated_sentences: "I heard the crying apparently, and I could vouch that the woman cried.

Sentences_from: Reszta kapitałów przeszła na sir Henryka. -- Ile wynoszą?
Sentences_to: The residue all went to Sir Henry."
Translated_sentences: The rest of the capital passed to Sir Henry. "How much are they?"

Sentences_from: Gdy doktor Mortimer wymienił mi pańskie nazwisko; domyśliłem się odrazu, że pan Sherlock Holmes wziął w swoje ręce tę sprawę i że pan tu przybyłeś z jego ramienia. Rzecz naturalna, że chciałbym się dowiedzieć, co pan Sherlock Holmes o tem myśli.
Sentences_to: When Mortimer told me your name he could not deny your identity. If you are here, then it follows that Mr. Sherlock Holmes is interesting himself in the matter, and I am naturally curious to know what view he may take."
Translated_sentences: When Dr. Mortimer mentioned your name to me; I guessed at once that Mr. Sherlock Holmes had taken the matter into his own hands, and that you had come here on his behalf. Naturally, I would like to know what Mr Sherlock Holmes thinks of this.

Sentences_from: -- Seldon wypatrzył, że jakiś chłopak zaopatruje go we wszystko.
Sentences_to: "Selden found out that he has got a lad who works for him and brings him all he needs.
Translated_sentences: Seldon saw that some boy was supplying him with everything.

Sentences_from: -- Artykuł wstępny traktuje o wolnym handlu. Pozwólcie mi odczytać z niego jeden ustęp: „Nie należy się łudzić, że taryfa protekcyjna osłoni nasz przemysł.
Sentences_to: "Might I trouble you for it--the inside page, please, with the leading articles?" He glanced swiftly over it, running his eyes up and down the columns.
Translated_sentences: -- The editorial deals with free trade. Let me read one paragraph from it: "We should not delude ourselves that the protective tariff will cover our industry.

Sentences_from: Taki głos ironiczny, chłodny, miał tylko jeden człowiek na świecie.
Sentences_to: That cold, incisive, ironical voice could belong to but one man in all the world.
Translated_sentences: Such an ironic, cool voice had only one man in the world.

Sentences_from: Łotr uciekał z tym butem w ręku. Tu właśnie go rzucił.
Sentences_to: And he hurled it away at this point of his flight.
Translated_sentences: The thief ran away with this shoe in his hand. That's where he threw it.

Sentences_from: -- Watson... -- szepnął baronet -- to było szczekanie psa!...
Sentences_to: "Watson," said the baronet, "it was the cry of a hound."
Translated_sentences: "Watson," the baronet whispered, "it was a dog barking!...

Sentences_from: Zataiłem to przed sędzią śledczym z pobudek, które pan zapewne zrozumie. Jako człowiek nauki, nie chciałem zdradzać się publicznie, iż wierzę w przesądy.
Sentences_to: My motive for withholding it from the coroner's inquiry is that a man of science shrinks from placing himself in the public position of seeming to indorse a popular superstition.
Translated_sentences: I hid this from the investigating judge for reasons that you will probably understand. As a man of science, I did not want to reveal publicly that I believed in superstition.

Sentences_from: -- Czy niema innych kandydatów do spadku?
Sentences_to: "There is no other claimant, I presume?"
Translated_sentences: "Are there no other candidates for relegation?"

Sentences_from: Na tle księżycowej tarczy odrzynały się skały, lecz żywy posąg nie stał już na ich szczycie.
Sentences_to: He might have been the very spirit of that terrible place. It was not the convict.
Translated_sentences: Against the background of the lunar shield, rocks were cut off, but the living statue no longer stood on top of them.

Sentences_from: Fakty następowały tak szybko po sobie, że trudno było je spisywać. Donosiłem ci, żem widział Barrymora, zakradającego się po nocy ze światłem w ręce do pustego pokoju.
Sentences_to: In my last report I ended upon my top note with Barrymore at the window, and now I have quite a budget already which will, unless I am much mistaken, considerably surprise you.
Translated_sentences: The facts followed each other so quickly that it was difficult to write them down. I reported to you that I saw Barrymor sneaking up after the night with light in his hand into an empty room.

Sentences_from: Gotówbym się założyć, że go niema w Merripit-House. Swoją drogą, przetrząśniemy dom od strychu do piwnic.
Sentences_to: But we'll search the house and make sure."
Translated_sentences: I'd be willing to bet he's not at Merripit-House. By the way, we will rummade the house from the attic to the cellars.

Sentences_from: Ale czy nie znajdujesz, Watson, że zbyt długo pozostawiłeś pupila bez swej opieki?...
Sentences_to: Don't you think, Watson, that you are away from your charge rather long?
Translated_sentences: But don't you find, Watson, that you've left your pet unattended for too long?...

Sentences_from: Wystraszył mnie takim argumentem i zmusił do milczenia.
Sentences_to: He frightened me into remaining silent."
Translated_sentences: He frightened me with such an argument and forced me to remain silent.

Sentences_from: Ale mam nadzieję, że nie będziemy już długo czekali.
Sentences_to: Broad bars of golden light from the lower windows stretched across the orchard and the moor.
Translated_sentences: But I hope we don't have to wait long.

Sentences_from: Ot, i druga sprawa nie obchodzi mnie osobiście, a jednak wykryłem rzecz bardzo ważną.
Sentences_to: I told them that they would have occasion to regret their treatment of me, and already my words have come true."
Translated_sentences: Oh, and the second thing I do not care about personally, and yet I detected a very important thing.

Sentences_from: -- Zmusi go do ostrożności, a może skłoni do ostatecznych czynów.
Sentences_to: "It may cause him to be more cautious, or it may drive him to desperate measures at once.
Translated_sentences: "It will force him to be cautious, or perhaps make him do the ultimate.

Sentences_from: Wystraszony, odparł, że przed chwilą biegły za jakąś dziewczyną. -- „Ale widziałem coś więcej -- mówił. -- Hugon Baskerville pędził tędy na swojej karej klaczy, a za nim leciał jakiś pies okropny, czarny, jakby szatan wcielony. Niech mnie Bóg broni, żebym kiedy jeszcze miał spotkać podobnego potwora na mojej drodze.
Sentences_to: But at length some sense came back to their crazed minds, and the whole of them, thirteen in number, took horse and started in pursuit. The moon shone clear above them, and they rode swiftly abreast, taking that course which the maid must needs have taken if she were to reach her own home.
Translated_sentences: Frightened, he replied that they had just been running after a girl. "But I saw something more," he said. Hugon Baskerville was speeding this way on his karej mare, and behind him flew a horrible dog, black, as if Satan incarnate. God forbid me, so that whenever I was still about to meet a similar monster on my way.

Sentences_from: Cały stok był usiany okrągłemi, foremnemi kamieniami.
Sentences_to: The whole steep slope was covered with gray circular rings of stone, a score of them at least.
Translated_sentences: The whole slope was dotted with round, moldy stones.

Sentences_from: -- To admirał Baskerville; służył w Indyach Zachodnich pod Rodneyem.
Sentences_to: "That is Rear-Admiral Baskerville, who served under Rodney in the West Indies.
Translated_sentences: "This is Admiral Baskerville; he served in The West Indya near Rodney.

Sentences_from: -- Mam nadzieję, że trzymaliście się panowie razem?
Sentences_to: "You have always kept together, I presume?"
Translated_sentences: "I hope you stuck together?"

Sentences_from: Wtedy baronet drzwi otworzył i wyszliśmy na palcach.
Sentences_to: Then the baronet gently opened his door and we set out in pursuit.
Translated_sentences: Then the baronet opened the door and we left on tiptoe.

Sentences_from: Cartwright w przebraniu chłopca wiejskiego, oddawał mi znaczne usługi.
Sentences_to: Cartwright had come down with me, and in his disguise as a country boy he was of great assistance to me.
Translated_sentences: Cartwright, disguised as a country boy, gave me considerable services.

Sentences_from: Im dłużej tu bawię, tem bardziej czuję się smutny i zaniepokojony. Te bagna rzucają cień na duszę.
Sentences_to: When you are once out upon its bosom you have left all traces of modern England behind you, but on the other hand you are conscious everywhere of the homes and the work of the prehistoric people.
Translated_sentences: The longer I play here, the more sad and anxious I feel. These swamps cast a shadow over the soul.

Sentences_from: Jechaliśmy za nimi; wysiedli gdzieś tutaj w pobliżu.
Sentences_to: We followed their cab until it pulled up somewhere near here."
Translated_sentences: We followed them; they got off somewhere here nearby.

Sentences_from: -- Ta ścieżka prowadzi do Merripit-House -- rzekł Stapleton. -- Może mnie pan zechce zaszczycić swojemi odwiedzinami?
Sentences_to: "A moderate walk along this moor-path brings us to Merripit House," said he. "Perhaps you will spare an hour that I may have the pleasure of introducing you to my sister."
Translated_sentences: "This path leads to Merripit-House," Stapleton said. "Perhaps you would honor me with your visit?"

Sentences_from: Przypuśćmy, że jest tam jakiś pies zdziczały -- byłoby to wyjaśnieniem tych wszystkich zagadek. Lecz gdzież taki pies ukrywa się?
Sentences_to: He is no one whom I have seen down here, and I have now met all the neighbours.
Translated_sentences: Suppose there's some feral dog out there -- that would explain all these puzzles. But where is such a dog hiding?

Sentences_from: -- Wolałbym, żebyś mi to opowiedział żywem słowem.
Sentences_to: "Perhaps you would kindly give me a sketch of the course of events from memory."
Translated_sentences: "I'd rather you tell me that in a word.

Sentences_from: -- To jednak dziwne! -- zauważył doktor Mortimer. -- Przeszukałem starannie cały pokój przed śniadaniem...
Sentences_to: "But it is a very singular thing," Dr. Mortimer remarked. "I searched this room carefully before lunch."
Translated_sentences: "But that's weird! Dr. Mortimer remarked. "I searched the whole room carefully before breakfast...

Sentences_from: Przez pół godziny czekałem w natężeniu, ale oprócz płaczu nie usłyszałem nic zgoła.
Sentences_to: The noise could not have been far away and was certainly in the house. For half an hour I waited with every nerve on the alert, but there came no other sound save the chiming clock and the rustle of the ivy on the wall.
Translated_sentences: For half an hour I waited in intensity, but apart from crying, I did not hear anything at all.

Sentences_from: -- Kiedy się dowiedziałeś o przebywaniu drugiego człowieka na bagnie?
Sentences_to: "Excellent, Watson! And how did you localize me?
Translated_sentences: "When did you find out about another man being in the swamp?"

Sentences_from: Należało odjąć wizycie wszelki charakter uroczysty.
Sentences_to: The more formal we made the visit the less information we might obtain.
Translated_sentences: It was necessary to deduct from the visit any solemn character.

Sentences_from: Zaczynam więc od dnia, następującego po tym, w którym wykryłem dwa bardzo ważne fakty: a więc naprzód, że pani Laura Lyons z Coombe-Tracey pisała do sir Karola Baskerville i wyznaczyła mu spotkanie o godzinie, w której śmierć znalazł; powtóre, że człowiek, przebywający na bagnie, ukrywa się w jednej z jaskiń na stoku góry.
Sentences_to: I start then from the day which succeeded that upon which I had established two facts of great importance, the one that Mrs. Laura Lyons of Coombe Tracey had written to Sir Charles Baskerville and made an appointment with him at the very place and hour that he met his death, the other that the lurking man upon the moor was to be found among the stone huts upon the hill-side.
Translated_sentences: So I begin with the day following that in which I discovered two very important facts: that is, forward, that Mrs. Laura Lyons of Coombe-Tracey wrote to Sir Charles Baskerville and assigned him a meeting at the hour when he found death; a repetition that a man, staying in a swamp, is hiding in one of the caves on the slope of the mountain.

Sentences_from: U stóp naszych leżało olbrzymia psisko, wielkości młodej lwicy; był to mieszaniec wyżła i brytana.
Sentences_to: In mere size and strength it was a terrible creature which was lying stretched before us. It was not a pure bloodhound and it was not a pure mastiff; but it appeared to be a combination of the two--gaunt, savage, and as large as a small lioness.
Translated_sentences: At our feet lay a huge dog, the size of a young lioness; it was a hybrid of a highlander and a brytan.

Sentences_from: Mówię to, żeby panu ułatwić rozwiązanie zagadki, nad którą pan zastanawiał się, patrząc na oparzeliska.
Sentences_to: All this, Dr. Watson, has been brought upon your head by your expression as you surveyed the moor out of our window."
Translated_sentences: I say this to make it easier for you to solve the riddle that you were thinking about when you looked at the burns.

Sentences_from: -- Jesteś w błędzie co do jego fachu.
Sentences_to: "Surely you are mistaken about his trade?"
Translated_sentences: "You're wrong about his trade.

Sentences_from: Maść w tej oto blaszance jest zapewne mieszaninę siarki i fosforu, którą pies był wysmarowany.
Sentences_to: On an emergency he could keep the hound in the out-house at Merripit, but it was always a risk, and it was only on the supreme day, which he regarded as the end of all his efforts, that he dared do it.
Translated_sentences: The ointment in this plaque is probably a mixture of sulfur and phosphorus, which the dog was smeared.

Sentences_from: -- Nazywa się Seldon. Wpakowano go do więzienia za morderstwo w Notting-Hill.
Sentences_to: "It is Selden, the Notting Hill murderer."
Translated_sentences: "His name is Seldon. He was put in prison for a murder in Notting-Hill.

Sentences_from: -- Czemuż więc nie uprzedziłaś pani o tem sir Karola?
Sentences_to: "Why then, did you not write to Sir Charles and explain this?"
Translated_sentences: "Why, then, did you not warn Sir Charles of this?"

Sentences_from: -- O ile można przypuszczać, te słowa zostały wycięte scyzorykiem.
Sentences_to: "So far as I can follow you, then, Mr. Holmes," said Sir Henry Baskerville, "someone cut out this message with a scissors--"
Translated_sentences: "As far as you can assume, these words were cut out with a pocket knive.

Sentences_from: Wróciłem do moich towarzyszów, aby zdać raport Holmesowi.
Sentences_to: "You say, Watson, that the lady is not there?" Holmes asked, when I had finished my report.
Translated_sentences: I returned to my comrades to report to Holmes.

Sentences_from: Ręczę panu za to słowem honoru.
Sentences_to: But he will never trouble anyone in this country again.
Translated_sentences: I vouch for this with a word of honour.

Sentences_from: Odrzekła mi na to bez namysłu:
Sentences_to: She met my difficulty with the utmost readiness.
Translated_sentences: She replied to me without a second thought:

Sentences_from: Księżyc w pełni zachodził za jedną z wyższych skał; wtem na jej szczycie ujrzałem postać męską, wyglądającą jak posąg.
Sentences_to: The moon was low upon the right, and the jagged pinnacle of a granite tor stood up against the lower curve of its silver disc.
Translated_sentences: The full moon set behind one of the higher rocks; Then, on top of it, I saw a male figure that looked like a statue.

Sentences_from: „Otóż ów Hugon pokochał (jeśli można tem mianem nazwać tak dzikie uczucie), pokochał zatem córkę czynszownika, dzierżawiącego grunta w pobliżu dóbr Baskerville.
Sentences_to: This, in truth, his neighbours might have pardoned, seeing that saints have never flourished in those parts, but there was in him a certain wanton and cruel humour which made his name a byword through the West.
Translated_sentences: "Well, this Hugh loved (if you can call it such a wild feeling), so he fell in love with the daughter of a landlord who leased land near the Baskerville estate.

Sentences_from: Nasz baronet zaczyna interesować się żywo piękną sąsiadką.
Sentences_to: The fact is that our friend, the baronet, begins to display a considerable interest in our fair neighbour.
Translated_sentences: Our baronet begins to take a keen interest in the beautiful neighbor.

Sentences_from: Jak wryty w ziemię, stał żołnierz na koniu, z bagnetem przez ramię.
Sentences_to: A steep curve of heath-clad land, an outlying spur of the moor, lay in front of us. On the summit, hard and clear like an equestrian statue upon its pedestal, was a mounted soldier, dark and stern, his rifle poised ready over his forearm. He was watching the road along which we travelled.
Translated_sentences: As if carved into the ground, a soldier stood on a horse, with a bayonet over his shoulder.

Sentences_from: Gdybyż tylko na tem poprzestał! ale on chce podobno wytoczyć proces doktorowi Mortimer za otwarcie grobu przedhistorycznego bez pozwolenia potomków, a to skutkiem... czaszki z epoki neolitycznej, odgrzebanej w Long-Dawn.
Sentences_to: If he would confine his energies to this all would be well, but there are rumours that he intends to prosecute Dr. Mortimer for opening a grave without the consent of the next-of-kin, because he dug up the Neolithic skull in the barrow on Long Down.
Translated_sentences: If only he had stopped there! but he reportedly wants to sue Dr. Mortimer for opening a prehistoric tomb without the permission of his descendants, and that's the result... skulls from the Neolithic era, unearthed in Long-Dawn.

Sentences_from: Kamerdyner przyniósł mi kawę do biblioteki; skorzystałem z tego, aby mu zadać parę pytań.
Sentences_to: The butler brought me my coffee into the library, and I took the chance to ask him a few questions.
Translated_sentences: The butler brought me coffee to the library; I used this to ask him a few questions.

Sentences_from: Przykro mi, że się panu narzucam, ale nie mogę puścić pana samego na trzęsawiska.
Sentences_to: I am sorry to intrude, but you heard how earnestly Holmes insisted that I should not leave you, and especially that you should not go alone upon the moor."
Translated_sentences: I am sorry to impose myself on you, but I cannot let you go to the bogs.

Sentences_from: -- Gdybyś nam się zwierzył z własnej i nieprzymuszonej woli, byłaby rzecz inna -- przekładał mu baronet -- ale powiedziałeś nam, a właściwie twoja żona powiedziała nam prawdę pod naciskiem, więc mamy ręce rozwiązane.
Sentences_to: "If you had told us of your own free will it would have been a different thing," said the baronet, "you only told us, or rather your wife only told us, when it was forced from you and you could not help yourself."
Translated_sentences: "If you confided in us of your own free will, it would be different -- the baronet told him -- but you told us, and actually your wife told us the truth under pressure, so we have our hands untied.

Sentences_from: -- Dziwne to pytanie... -- rzekła, udając obrażoną.
Sentences_to: "Really, sir, this is a very extraordinary question."
Translated_sentences: "It's a strange question," she said, pretending to be offended.

Sentences_from: W oczach wszystkich ów zbrodniarz był potworem i wyrzutkiem społeczeństwa; ona widziała w nim zawsze chłopaka z jasnymi kędziorami, którego nosiła na ręku i kochała, jak własne dziecko.
Sentences_to: To all the world he was the man of violence, half animal and half demon; but to her he always remained the little wilful boy of her own girlhood, the child who had clung to her hand.
Translated_sentences: In the eyes of all, this criminal was a monster and an outcast of society; she always saw in him a boy with bright burly, whom she carried in her arms and loved, like her own child.

Sentences_from: Holmes, patrząc na trupa, śmiał się, ręce zacierał.
Sentences_to: He had uttered a cry and bent over the body. Now he was dancing and laughing and wringing my hand.
Translated_sentences: Holmes, looking at the corpse, laughed, rubbed his hands.

Sentences_from: Mój przyjaciel i ja jesteśmy w zbrojnem pogotowiu.
Sentences_to: My friend and I are also ready for emergencies."
Translated_sentences: My friend and I are on military cleprehousing.

Sentences_from: Miałem tylko trzy pary: nowe żółte, stare czarne i te oto lakierki. Wczoraj zniknął jeden od żółtej pary, a dziś jeden od czarnej.
Sentences_to: "What! you don't mean to say----?"
Translated_sentences: I only had three pairs: new yellow, old black and these lacquers. Yesterday one from the yellow pair disappeared, and today one from the black one.

Sentences_from: Noc była tak ciemna, że przy najlepszym wzroku niepodobna było nic dojrzeć.
Sentences_to: The man is a striking-looking fellow, very well equipped to steal the heart of a country girl, so that this theory seemed to have something to support it. That opening of the door which I had heard after I had returned to my room might mean that he had gone out to keep some clandestine appointment.
Translated_sentences: The night was so dark that with the best eyes it was impossible to see anything.

Sentences_from: Wszak pan, sir Henryku, opuściłeś Baskerville-Hall w bardzo młodym wieku?
Sentences_to: But you were very young when you last saw Baskerville Hall, were you not?"
Translated_sentences: After all, Sir Henry, you left Baskerville-Hall at a very young age?

Sentences_from: Mieszka o cztery mile od nas.
Sentences_to: He is an elderly man, red-faced, white-haired, and choleric.
Translated_sentences: He lives four miles from us.

Sentences_from: Pożądanem jest, aby spadkobierca sir Karola mógł objąć jaknajprędzej majątek i prowadzić dalej chlubną działalność, przerwaną tak nagle i tak tragicznie. „Gdyby prozaiczne orzeczenie sędziego śledczego i rzeczoznawców nie położyło końca romantycznym historyom, krążącym na temat owej śmierci, nie łatwo byłoby znaleźć właściciela Baskerville Hall.
Sentences_to: I had observed some newspaper comment at the time, but I was exceedingly preoccupied by that little affair of the Vatican cameos, and in my anxiety to oblige the Pope I lost touch with several interesting English cases.
Translated_sentences: It is desirable that the heir of Sir Charles should be able to take over the estate as soon as possible and continue the glorious activity, interrupted so suddenly and so tragically. "If the prosaic ruling of the investigating judge and experts had not put an end to the romantic stories circulating about this death, it would not have been easy to find the owner of Baskerville Hall.

Sentences_from: Widuję chłopaka z zawiniątkiem codziennie, a czasem dwa razy na dzień. Poczekaj pan chwilkę.
Sentences_to: I have seen the boy again and again with his bundle. Every day, and sometimes twice a day, I have been able--but wait a moment, Dr. Watson.
Translated_sentences: I see a boy with a bundle every day, and sometimes twice a day. Wait a minute.

Sentences_from: Przez chwilę stałem z kartką w ręku, nie rozumiejąc, co znaczy to uwiadomienie.
Sentences_to: For a minute I stood there with the paper in my hands thinking out the meaning of this curt message. It was I, then, and not Sir Henry, who was being dogged by this secret man.
Translated_sentences: For a moment I stood with a piece of paper in my hand, not understanding what this awareness meant.

Sentences_from: -- Masz swoje pół suwerena; dostaniesz drugie pół, jak mi doniesiesz coś więcej.
Sentences_to: "Well, then, here is your half-sovereign. There's another one waiting for you if you can bring any more information.
Translated_sentences: "You have your half sovereign; you will get the second half, if you report something more to me.

Sentences_from: -- Za każdym razem portyer, stojący we drzwiach, wezwie portyera, siedzącego w sieni -- i temu dasz po szylingu.
Sentences_to: "In each case the outside porter will send for the hall porter, to whom also you will give a shilling.
Translated_sentences: "Every time the porter standing in the doorway will call the porter sitting in the hallway -- and you'll give it a shilling.

Sentences_from: Z wagonu pierwszej klasy wyskoczył mężczyzna krępy, o twarzy wesołej.
Sentences_to: We all three shook hands, and I saw at once from the reverential way in which Lestrade gazed at my companion that he had learned a good deal since the days when they had first worked together.
Translated_sentences: A stocky man jumped out of the first class carriage with a cheerful face.

Sentences_from: Czyżby on pozwalał sir Henrykowi starać się o własną żonę...
Sentences_to: Are you sure of what you say? How could he have permitted Sir Henry to fall in love with her?"
Translated_sentences: Was he allowing Sir Henry to seek his own wife...

Sentences_from: Stąpał powoli, zakradał się jakby, wreszcie stanął u drzwi bocznej oficyny.

Translated_sentences: He walked slowly, sneaked as it were, and finally stood at the door of the side outbuilding.

Sentences_from: Czy i teraz, łotrze, będziesz przeczył, że dawaliście sobie sygnały?...
Sentences_to: Now, you rascal, do you deny that it is a signal?
Translated_sentences: Now, rogue, will you deny that you gave each other signals?...

Sentences_from: Pierwszą myślą Stapletona było zapewne zgładzić go ze świata w Londynie.
Sentences_to: "It is possible that Stapleton did not know of the existence of an heir in Canada. In any case he would very soon learn it from his friend Dr. Mortimer, and he was told by the latter all details about the arrival of Henry Baskerville.
Translated_sentences: Stapleton's first thought was probably to kill him from the world in London.

Sentences_from: Ten sam jęk powtórzył się bliżej, dźwięczał w nim strach i ból.
Sentences_to: The cry had been loud on account of its vehemence, but it had pealed out from somewhere far off on the shadowy plain. Now it burst upon our ears, nearer, louder, more urgent than before.
Translated_sentences: The same moan repeated itself more closely, fear and pain lingering in it.

Sentences_from: -- Tak; po obu stronach biegnie trawnik, szerokości 6 stóp.
Sentences_to: "Yes, there is a strip of grass about six feet broad on either side."
Translated_sentences: -- Yes; on both sides runs a lawn, 6 feet wide.

Sentences_from: -- Oboje z żoną otrzymali po pięćset funtów.
Sentences_to: "He and his wife had five hundred pounds each."
Translated_sentences: He and his wife received five hundred pounds each.

Sentences_from: Nie sądziłem, że pan masz czas oddawać się takim zamiłowaniom...
Sentences_to: I didn't know that you found time for such things."
