Sentences_from: -- Na nieszczęście, nie potrafię tego powiedzieć.
Sentences_to: "That, unfortunately, is what I cannot tell you.
Translated_sentences: "Unfortunately, I can't say that.

Sentences_from: -- Jestem pewien, że będzie panu rad.
Sentences_to: "I am sure that he would be delighted."
Translated_sentences: "I'm sure you'll be glad.

Sentences_from: -- Obawialiśmy się tu wszyscy, że nowy baronet, po tragicznej śmierci sir Karola, nie zechce zamieszkać tutaj.
Sentences_to: "We were all rather afraid that after the sad death of Sir Charles the new baronet might refuse to live here.
Translated_sentences: "We were all afraid here that the new baronet, after the tragic death of Sir Charles, would not want to live here.

Sentences_from: Może pan zechce obejrzeć mój zbiór motyli?
Sentences_to: I think it is the most complete one in the south-west of England.
Translated_sentences: Maybe you would like to see my collection of butterflies?

Sentences_from: Od danego miejsca dzieliło nas kilka mil, lecz mogłem wyraźnie dojrzeć czarny punkcik.
Sentences_to: It was several miles off, but I could distinctly see a small dark dot against the dull green and gray.
Translated_sentences: We were a few miles away from the place, but I could clearly see the black spot.

Sentences_from: Ścigał go zapamiętale, podskakiwał, kręcił się wkółko. Ubawiony tem przyrodniczem _intermezzo_, postanowiłem czekać na rezultat pościgu.
Sentences_to: To my dismay the creature flew straight for the great mire, and my acquaintance never paused for an instant, bounding from tuft to tuft behind it, his green net waving in the air.
Translated_sentences: He chased him memorably, jumped up, hung around. Amused by this nature _intermezzo_, I decided to wait for the result of the chase.

Sentences_from: -- Watson, bierz kapelusz i laskę.
Sentences_to: "Your hat and boots, Watson, quick!
Translated_sentences: "Watson, take a hat and a cane.

Sentences_from: Ta mgła stanowi o jego życiu...
Sentences_to: There only remained the lamp in the dining-room where the two men, the murderous host and the unconscious guest, still chatted over their cigars.
Translated_sentences: This fog determines his life...

Sentences_from: -- To bardzo prawdopodobne -- przyznał Stapleton i westchnął z widoczną ulgą, jak gdyby kamień spadł mu z serca. -- A cóż pan o tem myśli, panie Holmes?
Sentences_to: "That seems the most reasonable theory," said Stapleton, and he gave a sigh which I took to indicate his relief. "What do you think about it, Mr. Sherlock Holmes?"
Translated_sentences: "It's very likely," Stapleton admitted, and sighed with apparent relief, as if a stone had fallen from his heart. "What do you think, Mr Holmes?"

Sentences_from: Przeskakiwał z kamienia na kamień, ze skały na skałę, jak dziki kozioł.
Sentences_to: We rushed over the brow of the hill, and there was our man running with great speed down the other side, springing over the stones in his way with the activity of a mountain goat.
Translated_sentences: He jumped from stone to stone, from rock to rock, like a wild goat.

Sentences_from: -- Nie; dostrzeżono twojego chłopaka i to mi posłużyło za drogowskaz.
Sentences_to: "No, your boy had been observed, and that gave me a guide where to look."
Translated_sentences: -- No; your boyfriend was spotted and it served as a signpost for me.

Sentences_from: Z jego okrzyków miarkuję, że odbiegł spory kawał od miejsca, z którego pies go spłoszył.
Sentences_to: By his cries he must have run a long way after he knew the animal was on his track. How did he know?"
Translated_sentences: From his cries I measure that he ran away a large part from the place from which the dog scared him.

Sentences_from: -- Przepraszam; to nie jest drobiazg -- zaprzeczył detektyw. -- Jakże to było?
Sentences_to: "Exactly," said Holmes, "however foolish the incident may seem. You have lost one of your boots, you say?"
Translated_sentences: -- Sorry; it's not a trifle -- the detective denied. "How was it?"

Sentences_from: Przywiozłem ze sobą Cartwrighta -- pamiętasz tego malca z hotelu -- on myślał o mnie: przynosił mi chleb i czystą bieliznę.
Sentences_to: I brought Cartwright down with me--you remember the little chap at the express office--and he has seen after my simple wants: a loaf of bread and a clean collar.
Translated_sentences: I brought Cartwright with me -- you remember that little one from the hotel -- he thought of me: he brought me bread and clean underwear.

Sentences_from: Wśród dni słotnych kapało mu pewno na głowę, kostniał z zimna wśród chłodnych nocy, a jednak nie opuszczał swej kryjówki. Ważny cel przykuwał go zapewne do tej nory...
Sentences_to: When I thought of the heavy rains and looked at the gaping roof I understood how strong and immutable must be the purpose which had kept him in that inhospitable abode.
Translated_sentences: In the midst of the days of the swarm, it must have been dripping on his head, ossifying from the cold in the cold nights, and yet he did not leave his hiding place. An important goal probably chained him to this burrow...

Sentences_from: Wprawdzie według rysopisu dorożkarza, rzekomy Sherlock Holmes był niższego wzrostu, lecz rysopisy bywają niedokładne.
Sentences_to: The beard might well have been the same. The cabman had described a somewhat shorter man, but such an impression might easily have been erroneous.
Translated_sentences: Although according to the description of the cab driver, the alleged Sherlock Holmes was of shorter height, the drawings are sometimes inaccurate.

Sentences_from: -- Czy jaśnie pan każe podać obiad? -- zapytał.
Sentences_to: "Would you wish dinner to be served at once, sir?"
Translated_sentences: "Are you clear about serving dinner?" "He asked."

Sentences_from: Dalej, rozumiałem, że gdyby utwierdziła się wiara w nadprzyrodzone siły, rządzące w Baskerville Hall, nikt nie zechciałby objąć starego zamku w posiadanie.
Sentences_to: I had the further motive that Baskerville Hall, as the paper says, would certainly remain untenanted if anything were done to increase its already rather grim reputation.
Translated_sentences: Further, I understood that if faith in the supernatural forces ruling in Baskerville Hall were confirmed, no one would want to take possession of the old castle.

Sentences_from: Pomiędzy nimi leżała dziewczyna, martwa, a obok niej Hugon Baskerville -- nieżywy.
Sentences_to: The moon was shining bright upon the clearing, and there in the centre lay the unhappy maid where she had fallen, dead of fear and of fatigue. But it was not the sight of her body, nor yet was it that of the body of Hugo Baskerville lying near her, which raised the hair upon the heads of these three daredevil roysterers, but it was that, standing over Hugo, and plucking at his throat, there stood a foul thing, a great, black beast, shaped like a hound, yet larger than any hound that ever mortal eye has rested upon.
Translated_sentences: Between them lay a girl, dead, and next to her was Hugon Baskerville -- dead.

Sentences_from: Stojąc przy tej furtce, biedny sir Karol ujrzał coś, co go tak wystraszyło, że stracił przytomność i zaczął biedz prosto przed siebie, aż mu tchu zbrakło i padł nieżywy z wycieńczenia i trwogi.
Sentences_to: As the old man stood there he saw something coming across the moor, something which terrified him so that he lost his wits, and ran and ran until he died of sheer horror and exhaustion.
Translated_sentences: Standing at this gate, poor Sir Charles saw something that had so frightened him that he lost consciousness and began to poverty straight ahead, until his breath was out of breath and he fell dead from exhaustion and fear.

Sentences_from: W blasku księżyca widziałem wyraźnie drobną postać naturalisty. Spostrzegłszy nas, zatrzymał się, ale po chwili szedł dalej.
Sentences_to: Not a word to show your suspicions--not a word, or my plans crumble to the ground."
Translated_sentences: In the moonlight, I could clearly see a small figure of a naturalist. Seeing us, he stopped, but after a while he walked on.

Sentences_from: Może jeszcze nie zapóźno, może zdołam go dogonić... Podążyłem w kierunku, w którym sir Henryk odszedł, ale nic mogłem go dostrzedz, aż wreszcie ukazał mi się na zakręcie drogi, tam, gdzie ścieżka, wiodąca przez trzęsawisko, odbiega od gościńca.
Sentences_to: But when I came to think the matter over my conscience reproached me bitterly for having on any pretext allowed him to go out of my sight.
Translated_sentences: Maybe not too far, maybe I can catch up with him... I walked in the direction in which Sir Henry had departed, but there was nothing I could see him, until he finally appeared to me at the bend of the road, where the path leading through the bog departed from the road.

Sentences_from: A gdzieżby chodził, i po co, jeśli nie dla prowiantowania więźnia?
Sentences_to: He passes along the same path at the same hour, and to whom should he be going except to the convict?"
Translated_sentences: And where did he go, and why, if not for the provision of the prisoner?

Sentences_from: Jak uważasz: co nam teraz uczynić należy?
Sentences_to: What do you think we should do?"
Translated_sentences: What do you think we should do now?

Sentences_from: O dwieście yardów przed domem, Sherlock kazał nam stanąć.
Sentences_to: We moved cautiously along the track as if we were bound for the house, but Holmes halted us when we were about two hundred yards from it.
Translated_sentences: Two hundred yards in front of the house, Sherlock told us to stand.

Sentences_from: Bądź co bądź, znajdowałem się wobec kobiety ślicznej, i teraz dopiero uczułem, ze moje zadanie jest trudne.
Sentences_to: But these, of course, are after-thoughts. At the moment I was simply conscious that I was in the presence of a very handsome woman, and that she was asking me the reasons for my visit.
Translated_sentences: After all, I was in the face of a beautiful woman, and only now I felt that my task was difficult.

Sentences_from: Donosiłem ci już, że, sądząc ze słów pocztmistrza, doszedłem do przekonania, iż ta próba niczego nie dowiodła.
Sentences_to: I have already explained that the testimony of the postmaster shows that the test was worthless and that we have no proof one way or the other.
Translated_sentences: I have already reported to you that, judging by the words of the postmaster, I have come to believe that this attempt has proved nothing.

Sentences_from: Obawiałem się zawsze anewryzmu serca, bo byłem bardzo do niego przywiązany.
Sentences_to: I feared that some disaster might occur, for I was very fond of the old man, and I knew that his heart was weak."
Translated_sentences: I was always afraid of anevrism of the heart, because I was very attached to it.

Sentences_from: Ożeniłem się i dlatego musiałem szpital opuścić; trzeba było założyć dom, postarać się o praktykę samodzielną.
Sentences_to: I married, and so left the hospital, and with it all hopes of a consulting practice. It was necessary to make a home of my own."
Translated_sentences: I got married and therefore had to leave the hospital; it was necessary to set up a house, try to practice independently.

Sentences_from: -- Ani w dzień śmierci sir Karola?... -- rzekłem z naciskiem.
Sentences_to: "Not on the very day of Sir Charles's death?"
Translated_sentences: "Not on the day of Sir Charles' death?... -- I said emphaticly.

Sentences_from: Przenosił wzrok z Holmesa na mnie i ze mnie na Holmesa.
Sentences_to: He looked sharply from Holmes to me.
Translated_sentences: He shifted his gaze from Holmes to me and from me to Holmes.

Sentences_from: Pan Stapleton mówił to z uśmiechem, ale z oczu jego było widać, że przywiązuje wiarę do tych pogłosek. -- Owa legenda oddziałała na wyobraźnię sir Karola -- ciągnął dalej -- i pewien jestem, że sprowadziła śmierć nagłą.
Sentences_to: He spoke with a smile, but I seemed to read in his eyes that he took the matter more seriously. "The story took a great hold upon the imagination of Sir Charles, and I have no doubt that it led to his tragic end."
Translated_sentences: Mr. Stapleton said it with a smile, but it was evident from his eyes that he was attaching faith to these rumors. "This legend captured Sir Charles' imagination ," he continued, "and I am sure it brought about a sudden death.

Sentences_from: Ożenił się tam z Beryl Garcia, najpiękniejszą kobietą w Costa-Rica, a sprzeniewierzywszy znaczną sumę z publicznych funduszów, zmienił nazwisko na Vandeleur, uciekł do Anglii i założył szkołę dla chłopców w Yorkshire.
Sentences_to: He married Beryl Garcia, one of the beauties of Costa Rica, and, having purloined a considerable sum of public money, he changed his name to Vandeleur and fled to England, where he established a school in the east of Yorkshire.
Translated_sentences: There he married Beryl Garcia, the most beautiful woman in Costa-Rica, and having misappropriated a considerable sum of public funds, changed his name to Vandeleur, fled to England and founded a boys' school in Yorkshire.

Sentences_from: Nasz wspólny przyjaciel, pan Stapleton, był tego samego zdania.
Sentences_to: Mr. Stapleton, a mutual friend who was much concerned at his state of health, was of the same opinion.
Translated_sentences: Our mutual friend, Mr. Stapleton, was of the same opinion.

Sentences_from: Muzeum Brytańskie objaśniło mnie, że był powagą na polu owadoznawstwa; odkrył dużo gatunków, które noszą nazwisko Vandeleur.
Sentences_to: "We now come to that portion of his life which has proved to be of such intense interest to us. The fellow had evidently made inquiry and found that only two lives intervened between him and a valuable estate.
Translated_sentences: The Britan museum explained to me that he was serious in the field of insect science; he discovered a lot of species that bear the surname Vandeleur.

Sentences_from: Zwykle dostawał dużo listów, bo wiedziano o jego dobrem sercu, i każdy w kłopocie udawał się do niego.
Sentences_to: He had usually a great many letters, for he was a public man and well known for his kind heart, so that everyone who was in trouble was glad to turn to him.
Translated_sentences: He usually received a lot of letters, because his good was known, and everyone in a fuss went to him.

Sentences_from: Łatwo mi przyszło dowiedzieć się o adresie mrs. Lyons.
Sentences_to: When I reached Coombe Tracey I told Perkins to put up the horses, and I made inquiries for the lady whom I had come to interrogate.
Translated_sentences: It was easy for me to find out about Mrs. Lyons' address.

Sentences_from: Odetchnęła swobodniej. -- Dzięki Bogu! Widzicie, panowie, jak ten łotr obszedł się ze mną!...
Sentences_to: She gave a long sigh of satisfaction.
Translated_sentences: She breathed more freely. "Thank God! You see, gentlemen, how this thief moved with me!...

Sentences_from: Podróż była przyjemna; czas zeszedł mi na zawiązywaniu bliższej znajomości z moimi towarzyszami i na bawieniu się z pieskiem doktora Mortimera.
Sentences_to: I looked back at the platform when we had left it far behind, and saw the tall, austere figure of Holmes standing motionless and gazing after us.
Translated_sentences: The journey was enjoyable; I moved on to make closer acquaintance with my companions and to play with Dr. Mortimer's dog.

Sentences_from: Po chwili wydał cichy okrzyk zadowolnienia. Spojrzałem w kierunku jego wzroku i zobaczyłem, że dorożka z siedzącym w niej mężczyzną, która zatrzymała się po drugiej stronie ulicy, jedzie znowu dalej.
Sentences_to: An instant afterwards he gave a little cry of satisfaction, and, following the direction of his eager eyes, I saw that a hansom cab with a man inside which had halted on the other side of the street was now proceeding slowly onward again.
Translated_sentences: After a while, he let out a silent cry of dissocia. I looked in the direction of his gaze and saw that the cab with the man sitting in it, who had stopped across the street, was going on again.

Sentences_from: Wychodziliśmy zawsze pod opieką tajnego policyanta, który nic podejrzanego nie dostrzegł.
Sentences_to: We have never gone out without keeping a sharp watch, and no one could have escaped our notice."
Translated_sentences: We always left under the care of a secret policeman who did not see anything suspicious.

Sentences_from: Lubi wprowadzać w zdumienie i zachwyt nad swym geniuszem wywiadowczym.
Sentences_to: The great ordeal was in front of us; at last we were about to make our final effort, and yet Holmes had said nothing, and I could only surmise what his course of action would be.
Translated_sentences: He likes to amaze and marvel at his intelligence genius.

Sentences_from: -- Bynajmniej. Zatrzymałem się u znajomego -- odparł doktor. -- Nie było żadnych poszlak, wskazujących, że chcemy stanąć w tym właśnie hotelu.
Sentences_to: "No, I had been staying with a friend," said the doctor. "There was no possible indication that we intended to go to this hotel."
Translated_sentences: "Not at all. I stayed with a friend -- the doctor replied. "There was no circumstantial evidence that we wanted to stand in this very hotel.

Sentences_from: Nigdy jeszcze nie widziałem go tak bezradnym.
Sentences_to: He stamped his feet upon the ground.
Translated_sentences: I had never seen him so helpless.

Sentences_from: Zaopatrzyliśmy go we wszystko, czego mu potrzeba.
Sentences_to: We have provided him with all that he can want.
Translated_sentences: We provided him with everything he needed.

Sentences_from: Morderca wodził niespokojnym wzrokiem dokoła, jak zwierz, gdy go doleci odgłos nagonki.
Sentences_to: The light beneath him was reflected in his small, cunning eyes which peered fiercely to right and left through the darkness, like a crafty and savage animal who has heard the steps of the hunters.
Translated_sentences: The murderer looked restlessly around, like an animal, when the sound of a bashing reached him.

Sentences_from: Wszystko mi sprzyjało; postanawiałem skorzystać z okoliczności i dziś jeszcze tę tajemnicę wykryć.
Sentences_to: Everything was working in my favour, and I swore that it should not be through lack of energy or perseverance that I should miss the chance which fortune had thrown in my way.
Translated_sentences: Everything favored me; I decided to take advantage of the circumstances and still discover this secret today.

Sentences_from: -- To zależy od rasy -- tłómaczył doktor Mortimer. -- Dość spojrzeć na okrągłą czaszkę sir Henryka, aby poznać, że jest celtyckiego pochodzenia, a Celtowie mają wrodzony zapał i zdolność przywiązywania się do ludzi i kraju.
Sentences_to: "It depends upon the breed of men quite as much as on the county," said Dr. Mortimer. "A glance at our friend here reveals the rounded head of the Celt, which carries inside it the Celtic enthusiasm and power of attachment.
Translated_sentences: "It depends on the race," Dr. Mortimer said. "It is enough to look at Sir Henry's round skull to know that he is of Celtic origin, and the Celts have an innate zeal and ability to become attached to the people and the country.

Sentences_from: -- Jest kilka legatów na drobne sumki i duży zapis na cele dobroczynne.
Sentences_to: "There were many insignificant sums to individuals, and a large number of public charities.
Translated_sentences: "There are a few legates for small sums and a large bequest for charity.

Sentences_from: Byliśmy tak przerażeni tem zjawiskiem, że nie wystrzeliliśmy w porę. Pies przebiegł mimo nas.
Sentences_to: With long bounds the huge black creature was leaping down the track, following hard upon the footsteps of our friend.
Translated_sentences: We were so horrified by this phenomenon that we did not launch in time. The dog ran in spite of us.

Sentences_from: -- Wątpię, czy co wieczór po dziesięć minut stawał przy furtce.
Sentences_to: "I think it unlikely that he waited at the moor-gate every evening.
Translated_sentences: "I doubt he stood at the gate for ten minutes every night.

Sentences_from: Jest uradowany. Trudno o większego entuzyastę i maniaka.
Sentences_to: My popularity would soon suffer if I were to carry out your orders to the letter.
Translated_sentences: He is overjoyed. It's hard to find a bigger enthusiast and a mania.

Sentences_from: Przysięgam sobie, że muszę ją odkryć, i to w ciągu dwudziestu czterech godzin.
Sentences_to: I swear that another day shall not have passed before I have done all that man can do to reach the heart of the mystery.
Translated_sentences: I swear to myself that I must discover it, and within twenty-four hours.

Sentences_from: -- Zatem wiesz, że drugi człowiek kryje się na bagnie?
Sentences_to: "You know that there is another man then?"
Translated_sentences: "So you know that the other man is hiding in a swamp?"

Sentences_from: -- Ale czemu o takiej godzinie?...
Sentences_to: "But why at such an hour?"
Translated_sentences: "But why at such an hour?...

Sentences_from: Daleko, w stronie Grimpen-Mire, błyszczało żółte światełko.
Sentences_to: Far away, miles off, in the direction of Grimpen, a single steady yellow light was shining.
Translated_sentences: Far away, on the Side of Grimpen-Mire, a yellow light shone.

Sentences_from: Wiedziałem, że samotność jest niezbędną mojemu przyjacielowi w chwilach, gdy zastanawiał się nad poszlakami spraw kryminalnych, gdy wyciągał wnioski i tworzył teorye, które okazywały się zawsze słusznemi.
Sentences_to: I knew that seclusion and solitude were very necessary for my friend in those hours of intense mental concentration during which he weighed every particle of evidence, constructed alternative theories, balanced one against the other, and made up his mind as to which points were essential and which immaterial.
Translated_sentences: I knew that solitude was necessary for my friend in the moments when he was thinking about the circumstantial evidence of criminal cases, when he was drawing conclusions and creating theories that always turned out to be right.

Sentences_from: -- Jaśnie panie, byłoby to szaleństwem z jego strony.
Sentences_to: "He would not do anything so mad, sir.
Translated_sentences: "Sir, that would be madness on his part.

Sentences_from: Ale w jaki sposób? Przedewszystkiem należało dowiedzieć się od pocztmistrza w Grimpen, czy telegram został oddany do własnych rąk Barrymora.
Sentences_to: Obviously the first thing to do was to see the Grimpen postmaster, and find whether the test telegram had really been placed in Barrymore's own hands. Be the answer what it might, I should at least have something to report to Sherlock Holmes.
Translated_sentences: But how? First of all, it was necessary to find out from the postmaster at Grimpen whether the telegram had been given to Barrymor's own hands.

Sentences_from: Takie wysnuwałem wnioski; opowiadam ci je, chociaż rezultat wykazał ich bezpodstawność.
Sentences_to: He was less surprised than I had expected.
Translated_sentences: That is my conclusion; I tell you them, although the result showed their groundlessness.

Sentences_from: Otóż zaleciała mnie subtelna woń białego jaśminu.
Sentences_to: In doing so I held it within a few inches of my eyes, and was conscious of a faint smell of the scent known as white jessamine.
Translated_sentences: Well, I was recommended by the subtle smell of white jasmine.

Sentences_from: Któżby miał ochotę mnie śledzić? Nikt mnie tu nie zna.
Sentences_to: You have nothing else to report to us before we go into this matter?"
Translated_sentences: Who would want to follow me? Nobody knows me here.

Sentences_from: Słysząc ich pijackie wrzaski, dziewczyna truchlała, lecz była z natury dzielną, więc opanowała strach i postanowiła ratować się. Ogromna brzoza osłaniała i do dziś dnia osłania okno tej narożnej komnaty.
Sentences_to: Now, the poor lass upstairs was like to have her wits turned at the singing and shouting and terrible oaths which came up to her from below, for they say that the words used by Hugo Baskerville, when he was in wine, were such as might blast the man who said them.
Translated_sentences: Hearing their drunken screams, the girl was dead, but she was brave by nature, so she mastered her fear and decided to save herself. A huge birch tree was guarded and to this day it still illuminates the window of this corner chamber.

Sentences_from: Gdybym nie ufał pańskiej odwadze i zimnej krwi, nie dawałbym panu takiej rady. Wierzaj mi pan, że to jest niezbędne.
Sentences_to: If I had not every confidence in your nerve and courage I would not suggest it, but it is essential that you should do it."
Translated_sentences: If I had not trusted your courage and cold blood, I would not have given you such advice. Believe me, sir, this is essential.

Sentences_from: -- To zależy od tego, dokąd pan idzie; jeżeli na łąkę i bagno, pójdę z panem.
Sentences_to: "That depends on whether you are going on the moor," said I.
Translated_sentences: "It depends on where you're going; if I go to the meadow and the swamp, I will go with you.

Sentences_from: Sir Henryk Baskerville słuchał uważnie, przerywając od czasu do czasu okrzykiem zdziwienia.
Sentences_to: Sir Henry Baskerville listened with the deepest attention, and with an occasional exclamation of surprise.
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry Baskerville listened attentively, interrupting from time to time with a cry of surprise.

Sentences_from: -- Mogę to tylko wywnioskować, że przed osiedleniem się na wsi, ten lekarz praktykował w mieście.
Sentences_to: "I can only think of the obvious conclusion that the man has practised in town before going to the country."
Translated_sentences: "I can only conclude that before settling in the countryside, this doctor practiced in the city.

Sentences_from: -- Jedno jest tylko miejsce, w którem mógł się schronić: dawna kopalnia ołowiu, w samym środku moczarów.
Sentences_to: "There is but one place where he can have fled," she answered. "There is an old tin mine on an island in the heart of the mire.
Translated_sentences: "There is only one place where he could have taken refuge: the former lead mine, in the middle of the swamp.

Sentences_from: Przez półtory godziny zapomniał o tej dziwnej sprawie; pochłonęły go obrazy nowoczesnych mistrzów belgijskich, mówił tylko o sztuce, na którą miał poglądy bardzo oryginalne. O naznaczonej godzinie stanęliśmy przed Northumberland Hotel.
Sentences_to: For two hours the strange business in which we had been involved appeared to be forgotten, and he was entirely absorbed in the pictures of the modern Belgian masters. He would talk of nothing but art, of which he had the crudest ideas, from our leaving the gallery until we found ourselves at the Northumberland Hotel.
Translated_sentences: For an hour and a half he forgot about this strange matter; he was absorbed by the paintings of modern Belgian masters, he spoke only about art, on which he had very original views. At the 100th hour we stood in front of the Northumberland Hotel.

Sentences_from: Istotnie ujrzałem malca, niosącego zawiniątko na plecach. Wspinał się pod górę powoli.
Sentences_to: There he was, sure enough, a small urchin with a little bundle upon his shoulder, toiling slowly up the hill.
Translated_sentences: Indeed, I saw a toddler carrying a bundle on his back. He climbed uphill slowly.

Sentences_from: Usłyszawszy, że sir Karol, z porady doktora Mortimer, zamierza opuścić Baskerville-Hall, postanowił działać bezwłocznie, w obawie, aby ofiara nie wysunęła się z jego szponów.
Sentences_to: "Driving back in the evening from Coombe Tracey he was in time to get his hound, to treat it with his infernal paint, and to bring the beast round to the gate at which he had reason to expect that he would find the old gentleman waiting.
Translated_sentences: Hearing that Sir Charles, on the advice of Dr. Mortimer, was about to leave Baskerville-Hall, he decided to act without obligation, fearing that the victim would not come out of his clutches.

Sentences_from: -- Urwała się trzecia nić! -- zawołał Holmes. -- To sprytny hultaj!
Sentences_to: "Snap goes our third thread, and we end where we began," said he.
Translated_sentences: "The third thread has broken!" Holmes cried. "He's a clever hoolith!

Sentences_from: -- Czyś pan kiedy słyszał wabienie błotnego ptaka, zwanego bąkiem?
Sentences_to: "Well, perhaps it was. Did you ever hear a bittern booming?"
Translated_sentences: "Have you heard the luring of a mud bird called a bittern?"

Sentences_from: -- Jeżeli panowie przyjrzycie mu się dokładnie, to zmiarkujecie, że piszący miał kłopot z piórem i atramentem.
Sentences_to: "If you examine it carefully you will see that both the pen and the ink have given the writer trouble.
Translated_sentences: "If you look at it carefully, you will be glad that the writer had trouble with pen and ink.

Sentences_from: -- Zaczniesz od dania szylinga portyerowi.
Sentences_to: "You will begin in each case by giving the outside porter one shilling.
Translated_sentences: "You'll start by giving the shilling to the portyer.

Sentences_from: Bądź co bądź urozmaica nam jednostajność życia i wprowadza do niego trochę komicznego pierwiastku.
Sentences_to: He helps to keep our lives from being monotonous and gives a little comic relief where it is badly needed.
Translated_sentences: After all, it diversifies the uniformity of life and introduces a bit of a comical element to it.

Sentences_from: W pierwszej chwili sądziłem, że to intryga miłosna. Dlatego zakradał się boso, dlatego był niespokojny.
Sentences_to: But whatever the true explanation of Barrymore's movements might be, I felt that the responsibility of keeping them to myself until I could explain them was more than I could bear.
Translated_sentences: At first I thought it was a love intrigue. That's why he sneaked bare boso, that's why he was restless.

Sentences_from: Zabił się na miejscu, bo skała wysoka i z tej strony prostopadle spuszcza się w kotlinę; druga jej strona łączy się z płaskowzgórzem. Biegnąc, więzień w przerażeniu swem nie spostrzegł, że stoi nad przepaścią.
Sentences_to: He has rushed about the moor in a crazy state and eventually fallen over here and broken his neck."
Translated_sentences: He killed himself on the spot, because the rock is high and perpendicular from this side it falls into the basin; the other side of it merges with the flat-nosed. Running, the prisoner, in horror, did not notice that he was standing on the precipice.

Sentences_from: Sir Henryk otworzył je; chłodny wiatr smagnął nas po twarzach.
Sentences_to: Sir Henry had flung it open, and the cold night wind beat in upon our faces.
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry opened it; a cool wind squid our faces.

Sentences_from: Po co tamten ukrywa się na bagnie?...
Sentences_to: Look at the noises on the moor at night. There's not a man would cross it after sundown if he was paid for it.
Translated_sentences: Why is that one hiding in the swamp?...

Sentences_from: W mgnieniu oka rozerwaliśmy pęta; na ziemi u stóp naszych leżała pani Stapleton.
Sentences_to: In a minute we had torn off the gag, unswathed the bonds, and Mrs. Stapleton sank upon the floor in front of us.
Translated_sentences: In the blink of an eye, we torn the shaves; on the ground at our feet lay Mrs. Stapleton.

Sentences_from: Wchodząc, zobaczył odrazu laskę w ręku Holmesa i podbiegł ku niej z okrzykiem radości. -- Tak się cieszę! -- zawołał. -- Nie byłem pewny, czym ją zostawił tutaj, czy w biurze portowem.
Sentences_to: As he entered his eyes fell upon the stick in Holmes's hand, and he ran towards it with an exclamation of joy. "I am so very glad," said he.
Translated_sentences: As he entered, he saw a staff in Holmes' hand and ran towards it with a cry of joy. "I'm so glad!" He cried. "I wasn't sure what he had left her here or in the port office.

Sentences_from: Po śmierci sir Karola zasięgaliśmy wiadomości o tym gentlemanie i dowiedzieliśmy się, że ma fermę w Kanadzie.
Sentences_to: On the death of Sir Charles we inquired for this young gentleman and found that he had been farming in Canada.
Translated_sentences: After Sir Charles' death, we inquired about this gentleman and learned that he had a farm in Canada.

Sentences_from: Hojność sir Karola dostarczyła nam środków po temu.
Sentences_to: Sir Charles's generosity has given us the means to do so.
Translated_sentences: Sir Charles' generosity provided us with the means to do so.

Sentences_from: Czy zastanawiałeś się w ciągu dnia nad tą sprawą?
Sentences_to: Have you turned the case over in your mind?"
Translated_sentences: Have you thought about this thing during the day?

Sentences_from: -- A potem wyczytałaś pani wiadomość o śmierci w gazecie miejscowej?
Sentences_to: "He appears to be a very consistent character. And then you heard nothing until you read the reports of the death in the paper?"
Translated_sentences: "And then you read the news of your death in the local newspaper?"

Sentences_from: Pytaj mnie pan, o co tylko chcesz -- nic nie zataję.
Sentences_to: Ask me what you like, and there is nothing which I shall hold back.
Translated_sentences: Ask me whatever you want -- I'm not going to hide anything.

Sentences_from: Po wyjściu naszych gości, Holmes zerwał się i zawołał:
Sentences_to: In an instant Holmes had changed from the languid dreamer to the man of action.
Translated_sentences: After our guests had left, Holmes jumped up and exclaimed:

Sentences_from: -- Czy historya ta nie jest interesującą?
Sentences_to: "Do you not find it interesting?"
Translated_sentences: Isn't this story interesting?

Sentences_from: Minąwszy najgłębsze moczary, szukaliśmy odbicia stóp na twardym już gruncie. Nadaremnie.
Sentences_to: But no slightest sign of them ever met our eyes. If the earth told a true story, then Stapleton never reached that island of refuge towards which he struggled through the fog upon that last night.
Translated_sentences: Passing the deepest marshes, we were looking for a reflection of our feet on the already hard ground. In vain.

Sentences_from: -- Dojrzał go zapewne stary gentleman przez teleskop.
Sentences_to: "The old gentleman with the telescope, no doubt.
Translated_sentences: "He must have been seen by an old gentleman through a telescope.

Sentences_from: -- Przypuszczam, że skłonił panią, dowodząc, że sir Karol chętnie poniesie wydatki na rozwód.
Sentences_to: "I presume that the reason he gave was that you would receive help from Sir Charles for the legal expenses connected with your divorce?"
Translated_sentences: "I suppose he persuaded you to show that Sir Charles would gladly incur the expenses of divorce.

Sentences_from: Przeszedł ścieżką obok nas i podążył dalej, a idąc, oglądał się na prawo i lewo, z widocznym niepokojem. -- Pst! -- szepnął Holmes. -- Baczność!
Sentences_to: "We are going too far," said Holmes. "We dare not take the chance of his being overtaken before he can reach us. At all costs we must hold our ground where we are." He dropped on his knees and clapped his ear to the ground. "Thank God, I think that I hear him coming."
Translated_sentences: He walked along the path past us and went further, and as he walked, he looked left and right, with apparent anxiety. "Pst! -- whispered Holmes. -- Attention!

Sentences_from: -- Panie Holmes -- rzekła wreszcie -- ten człowiek obiecywał, że mnie poślubi, jeśli uzyskam rozwód.
Sentences_to: "Mr. Holmes," she said, "this man had offered me marriage on condition that I could get a divorce from my husband. He has lied to me, the villain, in every conceivable way.
Translated_sentences: "Mr. Holmes," she said at last, "this man promised to marry me if I obtained a divorce.

Sentences_from: -- Nie tak łatwo go opisać. Miał może lat czterdzieści, był średniego wzrostu, ze dwa cale niższy od pana, ubrany był porządnie, miał dużą, czarną brodę, przyciętą spiczasto, i był bardzo blady.
Sentences_to: The cabman scratched his head. "Well, he wasn't altogether such an easy gentleman to describe. I'd put him at forty years of age, and he was of a middle height, two or three inches shorter than you, sir. He was dressed like a toff, and he had a black beard, cut square at the end, and a pale face. I don't know as I could say more than that."
Translated_sentences: "It's not so easy to describe. He was perhaps forty years old, of medium height, two inches shorter than the master, dressed neatly, had a large black beard, trimed pointedly, and was very pale.

Sentences_from: Cieszyło ją to widocznie, choć nie chciała słuchać moich wynurzeń miłosnych.
Sentences_to: I told her that since I had seen her I was in no hurry to leave it, and that if she really wanted me to go, the only way to work it was for her to arrange to go with me.
Translated_sentences: Apparently, she enjoyed it, although she didn't want to listen to my love asses.

Sentences_from: Serce zabiło we mnie żywiej. Tu musiał przebywać nieznajomy.
Sentences_to: Throwing aside my cigarette, I closed my hand upon the butt of my revolver and, walking swiftly up to the door, I looked in. The place was empty.
Translated_sentences: My heart beat more vividly. A stranger must have been here.

Sentences_from: -- Widzi pan te wzgórza woddali?
Sentences_to: "Well, you see the hills beyond?
Translated_sentences: "Do you see those hills that have been watered?"

Sentences_from: Mieliśmy się dowiedzieć jeszcze innych szczegółów, choć wiele rzeczy pozostało niewyjaśnionych.
Sentences_to: But more than that we were never destined to know, though there was much which we might surmise.
Translated_sentences: We were to find out other details, although many things remained unexplained.

Sentences_from: Poczciwy doktor okazuje nam dużo życzliwości, odwiedza nas prawie codzień.
Sentences_to: He has been very attentive to us, and hardly a day has passed that he has not called at the Hall to see how we were getting on.
Translated_sentences: A good doctor shows us a lot of kindness, he visits us almost every day.

Sentences_from: -- Wkraczamy teraz w dziedzinę domysłów -- wtrącił doktor Mortimer.
Sentences_to: "We are coming now rather into the region of guesswork," said Dr. Mortimer.
Translated_sentences: "We are now entering the realm of conjecture," Dr. Mortimer interjected.

Sentences_from: Tu -- domek przyrodnika Stapleton. Tutaj dwie formy: High Tore i Fulmire.
Sentences_to: There is a house indicated here which may be the residence of the naturalist--Stapleton, if I remember right, was his name.
Translated_sentences: Here -- the naturalist's house Stapleton. Here two forms: High Tore and Fulmire.

Sentences_from: Wiesz zapewne, że pomiędzy tą damą a Stapletonem zachodzą bardzo blizkie stosunki?...
Sentences_to: You are aware, perhaps, that a close intimacy exists between this lady and the man Stapleton?"
Translated_sentences: You probably know that there is a very close relationship between this lady and Stapleton?...

Sentences_from: Kochany Holmes! Moje poprzednie listy i depesze powiadamiały cię dokładnie i szczegółowo o wszystkiem, co się działo w tym ponurym zakątku.
Sentences_to: MY DEAR HOLMES,--My previous letters and telegrams have kept you pretty well up to date as to all that has occurred in this most God-forsaken corner of the world. The longer one stays here the more does the spirit of the moor sink into one's soul, its vastness, and also its grim charm.
Translated_sentences: Dear Holmes! My previous letters and dispatches informed you accurately and in detail of everything that was happening in this gloomy corner.

Sentences_from: W pierwszej chwili mój szwagier miał go za szpiega, ale niebawem przekonał się, że to gentleman i że działa na własną rękę w jakimś celu tajemniczym.
Sentences_to: At first he thought that he was the police, but soon he found that he had some lay of his own. A kind of gentleman he was, as far as he could see, but what he was doing he could not make out."
Translated_sentences: At first my brother-in-law thought he was a spy, but soon he became convinced that he was a gentleman and that he was acting on his own for some mysterious purpose.

Sentences_from: Czyżby Barrymore upatrywał kogoś lub czegoś na bagnie?
Sentences_to: It had struck me that it was possible that some love intrigue was on foot. That would have accounted for his stealthy movements and also for the uneasiness of his wife.
Translated_sentences: Did Barrymore see someone or something in the swamp?
